111.content: For as long as you can remember, your kind had been hunter-gatherers, roaming the wilderness of Great Sedimar, fleeing from the gargantuan beasts that roamed it. Your kind would have perished long ago if not for other species that had emerged roughly at the same time as humans. These species varied in size and shape but they were always bigger than humans by a long shot. They could have easily used humans as a food source or bait for larger game, but rather saw them as a resource and an ally. Humans helped keep their camps clean and helped with making tools and getting into places they couldn't reach. On rare instances there were clans out there that DID see humans as a meal, so if you were a nomad or refugee you had to approach new camps with caution. You were a human who....

11112.content:
With the fur covers thrown off, your adoptive father's large nude body was fully revealed. Slowly sitting up he began to stretch his grey furred back, the toned joints unwind, he then threw his massive arms over his head and unintentionally flexed his huge biceps. Blinking his golden eyes your father warmly smiled as he grabbed his huge and firm white furred pecs.

"I must say Zve, i thought i be the one waking you. After placing you in my chest you immediately were resting!", the huge wolf chuckled as he pulled his pecs apart to relieve the pressure of his buff beasts.

You had been the sole survivor of the human clan in the north. During the nefarious winter period you clan attempted to travel south in hopes of reuniting with their brethren. Despite being a youngling at the time, you could remember seeing the group get smaller and your parents growing weaker as they gave you most of their food. Help came too late as your father's clan the Alphas came across the few left of your clan. Despite giving aid both your parents passed and you were the sole human.

Despite being a human, the pack immediately brought you in. Winter was no longer a issue as the beautiful fur of the giant buff warriors kept you warm. You were soon fostered by the next chief Wolfren, treating you as his kin and teaching you of the pack's traditions and meanings. Even upon growing up you still felt close and grateful to have such a blessing from the spirits.

"Zve, little one?", your father's booming voice brought you out of the flashback. His clawed furry fingers reach in between his pecs, you were gently plucked up and pulled out of the furry canyon. Wolfren looked concerned as he placed you on his large palm and brought you before his bright eyes. "My son i was asking about your dreams, are you well? You usually are so lively in the morning."

You clasped your hands, feeling guilty for not paying attention. "I apologize father, i was just....reminiscing on the past. I know by now all members of the pack at 19 would be warriors, and i unfortunately can not fill that tradition for you."

Suddenly the whole space seem to shift as Wolfren stood up, his large pawpads stomping into the earth. The wolf had a look of shock and anger on his face. You dipped your head, of course you father would feel as ashamed as you did.

"Zve why in the spirits would you think that!?", Wolfren's deep voice boomed as he brought you to his massive chest. "Do you think I'm that vile that i have that shame for you? You are my son and you being a human does not change that, our pack does not treat our kin as such."

You widened your eyes as your father looked down at you with saddened eyes. "Please tell me, have i made you feel that way?", you shook your head furiously. "No father! None of this is because of you, I'm very grateful to be your son. I just feel shameful that i cannot be like the others!"

Wolfren suddenly tilted his palm, the soft furred flesh pressed you to his firm pec. The chief gently held you as he stood towering high. "My son, you do not need to feel this way. I Iove you now and will always, know that you are resilient and were made my son by fate."

You smiled as your father comforted you, his warm palm and heartbeat calming you. Wolfren smiled as well as he looked down, he kept you in his giant embrace for a little longer before pulling away. "Now then, i believe i shouldn't keep our pack waiting. I'll gather my supplies and we will go."

Nodding, your father set you down on the pile of furs. You looked up in awe as from your father's mighty stompers was his toned legs and large thighs. His white furred manhood rested on his rock sized. balls, despite being limp it was still a good 8 inches. You briefly saw his eight chiseled abs before he stepped over the pile, his balls bounced as you now looked up at his huge round rear. Despite being muscle the large cheeks bounced and grinded together with his steps.

Your father's tail swished above his humongous ass, he hummed as he grabbed a small sewn together loincloth. Pulling it up his thick thighs, Wolfren did need to use his paws to manoeuvred the clothing to contain his manhood. His butt was practically uncovered as a thin piece of the fabric ran between his cheeks. Next, Wolfren wrapped his leather waist strap around his wide torso and began attaching his hunting materials. His sacred blade, laid on his hip and the red fabric dyed with his his clan's blood was wrapped around his pulsing buff arm.

You took a breath, the hunts were rather intense. Anywhere on your father's large body was a resting spot for you and you could feel his intensity in his focus.

Wolfren placed a hand on his chest, giving a prayer to the spirits, his father, and ancestors. He asked for survival amd safety for everyone and you. Turning around he looked down grew determined for the hunt. Now then where to keep you during the event?

111131211.content:
"Bring 'em with us." Gilron commanded.
"Alrighty boys! Looks like we're having human for dinner!" Bone shouted enthusiastically.
Some of the men cheered with him, the others gave a half baked cheer, not really all the excited by the prospect of human meat. It was well known among most everyone that human meat was notoriously disgusting, only to be consumed at the most desperate of times where starvation would be otherwise assured. Some say they'd eat their own shit before they ever find themselves eating human meat. The likely reason some of the men cheered anyway was because the prospect of completing dominating another tribe and taking their humans as prisoners was empowering. Though, back in Gilron's father's day, the only time anyone really partook in eating human meat was either for drunk dares or because specific rituals or rites of passage required it. Most of the time they would use humans for any entertainment they could muster, and simply leave them to starve once they got bored. This wasn't out of any malicious intent, they were simply indifferent to the idea of humans. To them, it simply seemed like a waste of time and energy better spent on hunting. There are only very view sadistic and depraved individuals who actually enjoy eating humans, individuals who love the idea of conquering and having complete control over a being so much smaller than themselves; much like how a serial killer starts out by killing stray animals before moving onto bigger game.
Bone gave a devilish grin as he peeked into the box of terrified humans huddled together in furs, and notes that every single one is male. What a lucky find for him to find his favorite type of humans so far up north like this. Bone's fellow tribesmen look at him with annoyance, much like how one would look at a man child who overindulges in childish behavior; a trait that most grow out of long before his age. Just as bone was about to grab one of the screaming humans, he is stopped by Gilron.
"We're not gonna us 'em for your... games, Bone."
"Why not?!"
"Because we ain't fuckin' cubs."
"You're acting like the fucking cub, Gilron—"
"IT'S CHIEF TO YOU." interrupted Gilron with a warning, the look in his face stern and angry.
Bone swallowed, losing composure and his grip on the box. He reposed by folding his arms together and looking down at Gilron with a cheeky grin.
"You've gone soft, haven't you?" Bone countered, "why do you care what I do with these little shits, huh?"
Gilron didn't say anything, instead he just stared at Bone.
"You're getting old, Gilron. Only the old care about those as weak as them. Now, give me the box old man."
Bone put his hands out, expecting to receive the catch back from his chief. The other cats stared at the two, curious to see how this would play out, and who would be truly dominant in this outcome.
Gilron stared down into the box pensively with an expressionless face, the human that almost became Bone's prey looked up at him. Although he was terrified, he looked much more at ease under this cat's mercy than the other. The human shook as head, as if pleading with Gilron not to kill them. He recognized that look, the very same look his son gave him when he found him all those years ago. No, he knew he couldn't let Bone have them in good conscious. Damn if he was weak, he didn't care. At the very least, Bone didn't know that.
He looked up from the box and said, "You're right... maybe I have gone soft."
He closed the box and brought it to the still burning fire pit of the hares.
Bone shifted his glance worryingly. "H-hey... what do you think you're doing, Gilron?"
"It's chief to you. Say it again and I'll throw your toys into the fire before you even get to use 'em."
Bone quickly panicked. "W-wait, that's a waste!"
"Oh? I could've sworn you sayin' somethin' about them bein' little shits?"
"Those are rare little shits, Gil—" bone stopped himself.
Gilron started tipping the box on it's side, slowly moving it into the fire.
"Chief! I mean Chief!" Bone pleaded.
"Well, who's soft now?" Gilron snapped.
Bone gritted his teeth, unable to say anything. Gilron moved the box away from the fire, and approached Bone.
"Stay in line, and I might think about sparing one of these little shits for your... games," Gilron said, "besides, I have a better idea on how to use 'em. Giving 'em to you would be a real waste though."
"What do you plan to use them for, Chief?" one of the by-standing cats butted in and asked curiously.
Gilron did in fact have a purpose in mind, although he wondered if he should keep it a secret from his men for now. That purpose in question was...

He lifted himself up a bit to see if anything had appeared in the treeline and as he did and arrow slid across his cheek before making a wet thunk into a hare body behind him. A howl ran out and 20 wolves, all white with red war paint on them, poured out of the woods. A roar rolled across the snow from Gilron, and others joined the call. Bone jumped to his feet and faltered as he accidentally shot his passenger way up main street. He grumbled, spread his legs and sent some probing fingers in and guided the human up against his tail hole, where there was much less friction.
         Another arrow flew by his head and he dodged it, feeling a whisker lose and inch. He pulled his hand back out just in time to dodge an axe swing aimed at his face as a wolf snarled wordlessly at him. Bone dodged the second swing with less effort, and brought his palm up under the canines chin, hoisting the wolf up before bringing him back down headfirst into the snow. Bone placed a foot on the wolfs head and took his feet in his hands, twisting the whole wolfs body while keeping the head in place with his foot, an audible crack rang out from the neck and the wolf went stiff before ragdolling a moment later. Bone let go of the wolf before picking up his axe and chucking it into the treeline where he split the bowmans snout in two with it. A howl rang out from the treeline to the right and 20 more wolves poured from the otherside. The wasn't a quick raid, this was a pogrom. The wolves were trying to take out the Icefang's here and now. Bone turned again to see Lockjaw with one knife caught in the chin of a wolf while the other plunged into the dogs sternum and went down, disemboweling the wolf in one graceful motion. The cat laughed gleefully as he did it. Bone smiled at him before stars danced in his vision and he went face first into the snow, groaning as he rolled onto his back, the pressure squeezing Gilrons son and making him squirm, he coughed up a little blood where his lip was bleeding only to look up and see a wolf standing over him with a club, the wolf raised it with a snarl and...
11113121121111.title: He slides you into his loincloth

choices: No other hassles occur and the clan makes it home
111131211211111.content:
As the wolf winded up to deliver what would've been a powerful blow, a flash of amber caused the wolf to stumble and looked confused at the ivory hily protruding from his chest. He blinked and watched as his warpaint was mixed with his own blood. Bone groaned and got to his feet, feeling the human wriggle in the wrinkles of his asshole, wedged there from the fall, what an alien feeling.
         Bone gripped the handle and yanked the blade free of the wolf, who sputtered, a fountain of blood began pouring from the wound and the wolf stumbled forward, attempting to grapple Bone but ending up just hugging the larger cat around his waist. The hands of the wolf gripped the cats soft fur, looking for something to hold as his life drained from him. Bone put a reassuring hand on the wolfs head before reaching further down and drawing his chin up and drawing the knife across his throat, painting Bones right thigh red with blood. The wolf dropped to the snow and Bone tossed the knife back to Lockjaw.

         "Thanks, I owe ya brother." He said, and Lockjaw nodded before ducking as another wolf came running up swinging an axe at him, as he ducked his knife slid across the wolfs abdomen and sending a scarlet stream splattering across the snow. He pivoted back around and drove his other knife into the wolves skull. Bone picked up the club that had beaten the back of his head, just as another blood wolf ran up screaming, a stone mallet way to big for the pup pulled overhead. Bone jabbed with the club, punching it into wolf's open maw before pulling down hard, breaking his jaw and pulling some teeth in the process. Bone brought the club back up and uppercut the wolf, knocking him off the gtound a good two feet before he fell back to the earth, unconcious or dead, it mattered little.

         "What's with these whelps? This is slaughter...." Bone said to himself. Lockjaw answered anyway.

         "I heard they got hit by the polar bears as well this summer, their best were killed, these are probably all thats left." Lockjaw said picking up a spear and hurling it, the polearm passed clean through a wolf that was fighting Snowcoat. As the weapon passed through, Snowcoat gripped it and began wielding it against another wolf, as the one hit faceplanted, his spine severed. Bone laughed and lumbered towards two wolves advancing on the cart to try and salvage something from the slaughter. They saw Bone, blood dripping from his loincloth, their brothers blood painting his lower body and crystallizing in the cold, giving him a ragged look. He dropped the club, and opened his palms towards them, beckoning them to attack. The wolves bothe wielded spears and with a quick glance at each other they let out a yell and attacked the behemoth.

...

         Your were squeezed back and forth as the globular muscles surrounding you took turns supporting Bone's weight. You had already been chucked in here by gravity, and the Bone fingered you deeper within. By what you could hear over your own blood in your ears and the damp squelching of Bones cheeks shifting and sliding, the clan was in a battle. Gravity suddenly disappeared for a second before a shockwave ran through the muscles of Bone, jostling you and driving you right against his hole. The orifice clenched and grabbed an arm, but the movements were to sporadic and you were able to prevent yourself from being pulled into it. You had gone completely inside Gilron a couple times, and the pressure and heat is immense. Gilron did it when you were about to freeze to death, and he had little options. When you asked how he felt about it, he never answered, but that was an answer. He enjoyed it, but felt shame for feeling that way since you were his son. Bone seemed preoccupied, so if you got sucked in, he might not be able to keep from crushing you. So as he battled for the clan, you battled for yourself against a hungry, unaware maw that kept grabbing your limbs in an irregular pattern...

...

         Gilron groaned as he pulled his spear from the eye of a wolf, clutching his ribs. His vision was blurry with pain as he watched his men cut down the wolves. There had to be between sixty and seventy wolves in total, but they were no match for the veteren hunters of the Icefangs. Gilron glanced towards the meat sleigh to see Bone standing over a wolf with his foot on the canines throat. His claws extended and the foot pulled back, ripping out the wolves throat. Another wolf was getting back on his feet nearby, obviously taking a few fists to the face from the large cat. Bone walked up casually and lifted the wolf up to full height before delivering several quick punches to the chest of the poor whelp, stopping his heart. Bone turned and winked again at Gilron before sauntering off towards the next wolf in sight.

         After several more minutes of bloody battle, Gilron walked among his men to see what the casualties were. They had killed roughly 50 wolves, their corpses mangled and twisted in many gruesome ways. The cats only had one casualty, Greenfoot, a slim cat that was an expert climber and scout, he had been baited into the woods near the beginning of engagement and was surrounded and butchered. He killed three before they got him. Other than that everyone had a scratch or three but were still able to travel.

         "Gilron, we need to go after 'em, if we track them back to their camp we can finish this fight." Bone said and many men echoed his idea. Gilron leaned on his spear and made a shallow sigh

         "No, I'm not betting on the rumor that their best is dead, this was likely a culling, the blood wolves love to fuck, look at all these bodies, their barely twenty winters. This was an initiation, those who came back would join their pack, and those who didn't aren't worth the time to give a proper burial." Gilron stated, and the enthusiasm died some. He continued, looking at Bone and Lockjaw. "You two know this, the wolves are usually more organized and lethal, if that was the true pack, our casualties would probably be half our hunters." Gilron said. Bone hissed.

         "Do you doubt our strength Chief? Don't use yerself to measure our prowess, if the clan is weak it falls on the leader!" Bone spat, and many muttered agreement. Gilron tensed, this was a different kind of challenge, he had to tread carefully.

         "I didn't say that, we are strong, but cunning and numbers can beat strength, we must have cunning as well if we were to fight them. But we have others to worry about, how is everyone's humans?" Gilron said. Many blinked, remembering their new companions, and the next few seconds were filled with grunts as the cats pulled their humans from whatever recess they had ended up in. Bone slid a hand behind him and dug deep, Gilron kept a neutral expression but anger burned inside him that his son was in this Brutes ass.

...

You were pulled into light with quiet pop, leaving the warm, tight confines of the Cats rear and pulled around into his palm. You blink and look up at the amused expression of Bone. Grunts of approval and disapproval rang out around however. Most humans seemed to have survived in pristine condition, but about five or so lay dead in some form or another in their hosts palms. Another four couldn't even locate their humans, whether their bodies had claimed them or they had fallen out and trampled in the battle was unknown. Your father suddenly sighed, his vision glanced over you but didn't linger, but his eyes told you he was relieved you were alright.

         "So nine dead? I assumed it would be worse, let this be a lesson, always remember where the humans are, and what your body is capable of." He said, turning and looking at a solid tan Smilodon that had sharp green eyes, his loincloths belt was made of a briar vine, its thorns poking his flesh. "Thornfur, bury Greenfoot and see if his human is still alive, send his spirit to the Far Wilds. Catch up when you can, Bone stay with him." Gilron said brushing past the big cat, his scent washing over you in his passing and calming your senses. You watched your father go and the rest of the clan followed, the convoy leaving the scavenged bodies of the wolves behind. Bone spat again, and eyed Thornfur.

         "Shaman duties suck huh Thorn?" Thorn just blinked then began searching Greenfoot, removing his necklace and putting it in a pouch on the briar belt. He moved his hand to the belt and grunted as he forced one of the thorns into his side, drawing blood and dabbing it up with his thumb. He took the digit and drew a crest on Greenfoot's forehead, closing his vacant eyes with his other fingers. Bone grunted approval and deposited you on his shoulder. The blizzard was dying down, but it was still cold as sin out here.

         "So did ya like it in there, Lad?" Bone asked eyeing you as Thornfur worked. You laugh a little.

         "Not really, you almost pulled me up into you, maybe next time let's avoid situations where that happens." You say shivering. Bone scoffed and looked down at his painted belly and loins.

         "Ah shite, My cloth is a mess, those stains aren't coming out." He said in a somber way.

         "Why is your cloth different from the others?" You ask. He turns and smiles, the first time he seemed happy to answer you,

         "I'm not originally an IceFang, I come from the GiantClaws, the IceFangs are another species in a sense, I come from the largest of the Sabres. My clan died out when I was a cub, I looked enough like them that they accepted me, but when I got to full size, it was obvious that I'm a cut above them." He said. Thornfur looked up and scoffed, and that got a hearty laugh from Bone. "My cloth is made of Hemp, a plant that grows in the south. It was my fathers, it has seen much blood on its strands." He said as Thorn covered Greenfoot before standing up and walking off, and Bone followed.
111131211211111.title: One of Lockjaws knives fly into the wolf's ...

1111312112111112.content:
Thorn searched the corpse of Greenfoot, only to find the body of the deceased Smilodon’s human, tucked away in the chest pocket of his coat fashioned from leather and fur. To Thorn’s surprise, the body hadn’t retained any visible injuries, not even being crushed under the weight of the corpse. But the human was blue in the face, likely suffocating to death as Greenfoot’s corpse constricted him of air. Thorn shook his head disappointedly, then laid the human’s body on Greenfoot’s chest, once again drawing his own blood as he painted another symbol. He hummed a mantra of sorts, probably giving the human the same passing rites as his fallen comrade.

         You watched this, becoming somewhat demoralized. A third of the humans your father had recruited had been lost now. Damn, that leaves only 20 left, you thought to yourself. You shook it off, there was nothing you could’ve done. Better to move on than to linger on the loss of humans you never knew. At the very least, the fallen humans had received a proper send off, thanks to Thorn. Thorn was the one after all, who had the responsibility of sending everyone to whatever plane lies beyond death. This was just another one of the many sendings he’d do in his life. You looked at the face above you, and saw that Bone also had a disappointed grimace. It may’ve surprised you but considering the side he’d revealed to you so far, seeing his reaction gave you some reassurance.

         You lightened the mood and broke the silence by saying, “hey, Bone, mind if I ask you something?”

         Bone shifted his eyes towards you without moving his head, “aye, go on, lad.”

         “Why is your name Bone?”

         He chuckled faintly, “it’s short for Bone Snapper, me lad.”

         Your mouth opened preparing another question, but you stopped as you put two and two together; instead, you said, “I’m guessing there’s a reason you got that name.”

         Bone smirked slightly, “knew ye were smart enough to put two and two together,” he stated, then followed up with, “but why tell ya, when I can show ya?”

         Admittedly, you turned a bit cold by that statement, unable to tell if he was joking or threatening you. Before you could respond, Bone suddenly whipped an ivory knife behind himself with his other arm. He seemingly pulled it from his hip holster without making any indication of doing so. The knife whistled as it flew across the air before making a loud thud as it made its mark. The unexpected jolt had thrown you off his shoulder, but Bone caught you in an instant before you could even realize you were falling. A large canid shadow fell from the trees some distance away and slammed into the earth below. The morbid howling and cries of a wolf echoed across the forest. When you regained your footing, you saw the wolf clasped it’s leg in agony as the knife had landed deep into its knee. The leg had been completely bent backwards; the whiteness of bone could be seen piercing out of the now loose skin of the kneecap. Bone had thrown the knife with so much force that it broke the wolf’s knee in an uncountable amount of pieces. Ouch, was all that came to mind. Bone had answered your question in the most brutal fashion he could have.

         “Thank ye, Thorn,” bone said, “dunno how you spot that bugger from all the way ‘ere.”

         Thorn gave a nod and a thumbs up in response. You looked at Thorn bewildered, unaware that he gave any sort of signal that someone was hiding up in the trees. Glancing at the forest some yards away, the foliage the leaves provided meant the wolf must’ve been well camouflaged. Yet somehow, Thorn had not only spotted the practically invisible wolf from so far away, but also gave an accurate enough indication for Bone to strike the wolf without fail. This seamless and incredible teamwork all happened with you being none the wiser. You knew you had a lot to live up to if you ever wanted to prove your worth to the tribe.

         “Thorn! How did you do that?” you asked incredulously.

         “That’s Thorn for ya,” said Bone, “he’s spotted and hit birds from a mile away.”

         Thorn gave no indication of showing off or any sense of pride, he merely shrugged.

         “Don’t know how ‘e does it, but the lad’s wasting his gift on shaman duties,” Bone said with a mocking tone on the last part.

         Thorn actually seemed to take offense to Bone’s last statement, glaring at him with irritation on his brow.


Bone approached Thorn, gesturing for him to stick his palm out. As he did, Bone slid you from his clawed and burly hand onto Thorn’s lean and muscled one.

         “Gonna need ye to hold onto ‘im while I take care of the mutt over there,” Bone said, then looked down to you and gave you a reassuring grin.

         “Wait, Bone?” you inquired.

         But he ventured deeper into the forest, leaving you in the care of another stranger. Naturally, you were a bit worried. You hadn’t even gotten use to being with Bone yet, and now, yet again, you were in the hands of an entirely different Smilodon. You looked up at Thorn pensively, then he looked to you on his palm. The two of you just stared awkwardly at each other, but after few moments, the giant gave you a soft smile. You felt the back of his clawed finger pet your back, which startled you just a bit. He continued stroking you ever so gently, being cautious and aware of his own strength. Your worries faded as quickly as they came, as you felt genuine kindness emanate from this Smilodon, putting you at ease. You felt the soft vibration of his quite, barely noticeable purring.

         It was strange. You’ve always known Smilodons to be about survival of the fittest, but these giants were not at all heartless, the opposite in fact. But you knew their priority was on survival. Surviving meant they weren’t granted the luxury of being very expressive with their emotions. Still, like your father, there always laid a softness inside their rough exterior, in each of them.
1111312112111112.title: Bone and Thornfur are attacked

11113121121111121.content:
(Every chapter that says "Continue..." at the end of it means that I'm not finish with my addition. Please wait until I add at least two paths again to add your own addition, as there is still more to come. Thank you.)


Bone grabbed the wolf by an ear and banged his head against the tree, pinning the canine’s injured leg against the snow-covered dirt with his own. Amazingly, the canine hid his pain and merely grunted. Bone leaned his forearm against the canine’s neck, pinching him against the tree.

         “How many more of ya are up there?” Bone asked.

         The wolf didn’t respond, instead he just glared at Bone hatefully. Bone reacted to the response with an increase of pressure on the wolf’s injured leg. The wolf gritted his fangs in anguish, his eyes clenched shut as he gasped for air.

         “I’ll ask again… Are ye the only bugger left?” asked Bone.

         The hardened wolf still refused to say anything. Bone didn’t seem bothered. He grinned gleefully, menacingly, as he put all of his incredible mass onto the leg now, testing the wolf’s limits. The wolf bared the pain as best he could, until he could bare it no longer.

         The wolf yelped, then screamed, “Y-Y-YES! PLEASE, ENOUGH! I’M THE LAST ONE!”

         Bone, with a familiar sadistic smile whispered, “I. Don’t. Believe. Ya.”

         “I SWEAR! I SWEAR ON LUNA! ON STELIOS! ON LUPUS! BY ALL THE GODS! JUST STOP!”

         “And how the fuck are yer gods and goddesses supposed to convince me?!” Bone asked, still not relieving any pressure.

The wolf whimpered, unsure of what else to say.

         “Ye were planning on killing me and my human while ye were hiding in the trees like a damned monkey, weren’t ya?!” accused Bone, “I ain’t givin’ ya a quick death, you fuckin’ maggot!”

         Bone surprised even himself with those last words, confused as to why he became suddenly so enraged and defensive over the thought of Gilron’s son. He shook it off. Caught in the moment, he thought, and continued. The wolf barely opened his eyes in surprise upon hearing about Bone’s human, but it was not missed by Bone.

         “It’s true then” bone said, “yer stalking my human?”

         The wolf shook his head ‘no’ violently in response. The wolf’s supposed denial pissed Bone off even more. Still, the fact of the matter was that Bone wanted to get back at a wolf, any wolf, for Greenfoot’s death. Any wolf that thinks they can disrespect his tribe will suffer his wrath for it. He gripped the injured wolf’s wrist, then pulled on it as hard as he could. The wolf screeched in pain to no avail. Then, Bone finally pulled hard enough to hear a pop, causing the arm to dislocate out of its socket.

         “STOP! STOOOOOOP! I’LL TELL YOU WHERE YOUR HUMANS ARE! JUST STOP!” the wolf pleaded desperately.

         Bone raised his eyebrows in surprise, then remembered the four humans they lost in the battle with the wolf tribe. Maybe what remained of the wolves came back to reap the losses. Finally, after so much torture, Bone relieved the pressure, knowing that he’d went above and beyond breaking this wolf for it to be any threat now.

         “What humans? Where ja’ find ‘em?” Bone asked.

         The wolf gasped in relief, “we found them… in the… snow… when we attacked you…” the wolf claimed, pausing every few seconds to catch his breath.

         “How many?”

         “About five… I think…”

         Bone thought for a moment. The Ice Fangs had only four missing humans, so he wondered if this wolf was lying, or if it was even their humans to begin with. Still, the wolf kept this information hidden until he was at his most desperate. If there was a chance these humans were the Ice Fang’s, they knew they couldn’t let the wolves disrespect the tribe by claiming them.

         “Where are they?” Bone demanded.

         The wolf hesitated and said nothing. Bone grabbed the wolf’s one working arm and began to pull that one as well.

         “AHHG! FUCK! NO! STOP! THEY SHOULD BE AT OUR CAMP BY NOW,” the wolf cried.

         Bone did not let up though.

         “What do ye mutts want with ar’ humans?!”

         “A RITUAL! THEY’RE GOING TO USE THEM FOR A RITUAL!”

         “What ritual?!”

         “THE RITUAL OF THE WARRIOR!”

         “What are ye gonna do with ‘em?!”

         “T-T-THEY’RE… GOING TO…” the wolf stopped once again, tears coming down his eyes now as he desperately wanted to hide the information.

         Bone pulled harder.

         “THEY’RE GOING TO EAT THEM ALIVE, SWALLOW THEM WHOLE!” the wolf screamed.

         Bone snorted in disgust, “ye wolves want a creature so much weaker and smaller than yerselves to suffer and burn alive in yer bellies? Ye don’t even ‘ave the decency to kill ‘em first? All for what? Yer fookin’ rituals? Ye sick wolves just want to torture small creatures for the sake of it, don’t ya?!”

         The wolf sunk his head low into his lap in shame. In the moment, the wolf likely knew he was dead. He had just betrayed his kin by revealing the knowledge of their plans, a plan that could save their dying tribe from the Polar Bears that had all but decimated them. Even if the sadistic Smilodon let him live, there was no going anywhere with his injuries. Even if by some miracle he made it back, his kin would kill him then and there. He began to snicker manically, which transitioned into a full-blown laugh. He looked up at Bone and gave him a maniacal smile.

         “If it means we can become the ultimate warriors and save our people, then we’ll sacrifice as many humans as it takes!”
11113121121111121.title: Bone interrogates the wolf

111131211211111211.content:
You’d had seen the torture Bone inflicted on the unfortunate wolf. You looked away, unable to stomach much of the screaming or bleeding. You thought it was all very unnecessary, and Thorn thought the same. He scrunched his snout as he winced just hearing it. He’d respectfully turned around so you wouldn’t have to witness it any longer. Since you couldn’t hear what the two were saying anyway, you covered your ears, waiting for it to be over. Thorns ears perked, he suddenly jolted his head back in Bone’s direction, then sniffed the air. His eyes opened wide and became entirely slit, his stare intense, his breathing rapid, and his eyes darted left and right as he focused his gaze deep into the white greenery lowly lit by the sunset.

         “Thorn? You okay?” you asked.

         Thorn’s gaze fell on you now, his brows wrinkled with anxiety, as if pondering something. Thorn grunted apologetically to you, then his long maw became fully agape. Before you could even react, you were sprawled face first onto Thorn’s large, slimy, pink member of a tongue.

         “W-WHAT THE HELL?! THORN?!”

         His maw clamped shut, the zigzag pattern of his fangs aligning before casting you into darkness. A jolt of momentum threw you far back, and you landed just inches away from his uvula and the tunnel that was his throat. You would’ve fell down the throat if the tongue hadn’t pushed you back to the center. The heat was immense, you felt the rapid thumping of his heartbeat, his breathing now labored. On the outside, Thorn sprinted on all fours as he made a mad dash into the forest.

----------------------------------------------

Bone found himself in flight as he was thrown several feet backwards, and just as he was, a flurry of arrows planted themselves where he stood in the snow-covered ground. A good number of them struck the battered wolf, the one buried deep in his head brought instant death.

         Bone could only react with, “WHAT!” before being shoved behind a tree.

         Thorn, being much smaller than the muscle bound Smilodon, had managed to carry them both to safety just in the nick of time. An arrow whizzed past the tree, barely missing Thorn’s head. Thorn signaled for Bone to keep his head low, peaking his own head slightly beyond the protection of the trunk. He ducked his head back just as quickly as an arrow struck the tree’s base. He had seen it now though, a dozen or so wolves perched on the tree branches like hawks, as their eyes glowed white in the darkness. Only creatures such as Thorn would’ve noticed in time, but just barely. Any Smilodon, even an impressive one such as Bone or Gilron, would’ve never survived the encounter.

         Bone’s curiosity betrayed his instincts, and he glanced beyond the tree just for a moment. His appalled expression indicated that he saw it too. He knew these were no wolves, or they would’ve never stoked this much fear in him. These were the living folktales he’d witnessed only once before in his life, the ones who invaded every nightmare he’d had since he was a cub. These were the same monsters that wiped out his birth tribe. The fact that so many had been so close to him and he hadn't even noticed one, terrified him. It reaffirmed the stories of old; monsters who made not a whisper, not a sound even as they hunted in the night. The wolf who fell from the trees was but a meager tribesman, but he was alongside these monsters somehow. A fact dawned on Bone. They had seen, no, permitted the torture of the wolf through inaction, then killed him themselves. The meager wolf couldn’t have been affiliated with these monsters, or he would’ve pleaded for their help. Despite being shoulder to shoulder with them, he was not even aware of their presence or that he was being watched. If they had been the ones to attack the Ice Fangs today, there would be no one left alive to tell the tale.

         All of them were at least a foot taller than bone, protected head to toe in an unnatural amount of muscle mass and fur. Instead of being gnarled and scarred from a lifetime of fighting like most warriors, they were unscarred, unkempt, and looked like they had not even seen a scrape from battle. Yet, each one likely saw more battle than Gilron and Bone would’ve seen in a lifetime combined. They had a grace to them, which was contradicted by their fatal nature. Combined with the paleness in their eyes that stared intensely at the two Smilodons, as if they were evaluating their prey; they looked very unnatural, but fascinating.
Bone gripped the knife to his hip as he lay in the cold, snow-covered roots of the tree, readying himself for whatever was to come. Thorn shut his eyes and took a deep breath through his nose. He stood up, walked into the open, and revealed himself to the monsters that yearned to hunt them.

         “THE HELL ARE YE DOIN, IDOT!? THEY’LL KILL YA!” Bone screeched.

         However, Thorn showed no fear, making full eye contact with the predators. His eyes glowed a bright green, his pupils changed from sharp slits to large, soft, and rounded ones. Ones unlike any a Smilodon would be naturally born with. The wolves’ eyes were soulless and devoid of emotion. Thorn’s were lively and passion filled. The glimmer of determination in Thorn’s eyes told them he was prepared to kill more than a couple of them if he were to fall today. The wolves reacted to this by slowly sliding back into the darkness of the foliage, not once taking their attention off Thorn. Soon enough, they melded into the leaves like the wind, soundlessly retreating into the forest and allowing their prey to live another day.

----------------------------------------------

Thorn and Bone huffed a sigh of relief when they were sure the monsters were gone. Bone still remained covered under the safety of the tree trunk, not taking any chances.

         “Are they gone?” asked Bone.

         Thorn nodded.

         Bone relaxed upon his response, only to immediately tense up again when a thought crossed his mind. His eyes widened as he grabbed Thorn by the shoulders and desperately shook him.

         “Thorn! Me human!”

         Thorn put a palm on Bone’s shoulder, trying to calm him. He guided Bone’s hand with his own and placed it under his chin, then opened his maw and slid the human onto Bone’s cream-colored palm. A wave of relief, confusion, and anger had overcome Bone, the still present adrenaline clouding his mind. To see your unconscious and slobber covered form exit his tribe brother's mouth, as if you were someone else's prey and not his, enraged him. He grabbed his tribe brother by the neck and pinned him against the tree, his face contorted in fury, his gummed fangs protruding as he growled ferociously. A puzzled Thorn merely stared at Bone with a quizzical expression, without even the slightest bother about being pin down.

         “THE HELL WAS ‘E IN YAR MOUTH FOR?” demanded Bone.

         Thorn blinked meekly in response, understanding the anger had made Bone forget he could give no answer. Bone’s eyes lowered, he looked at the human kept safe and sound in his clawed hand, then his senses returned to him. He recognized his tribe brother’s cautious efforts to protect you. Thorn coughed, calling back Bone’s attention. Bone looked back at him apologetically and released his grip, chuckling quietly with embarrassment.

         “Oi… Sorry, lad. Thought the worst…” said Bone.

         Thorn gave an empathetic nod.

----------------------------------------------

You were awakened by the commotion of your giant guardians. You felt the groggiest you’ve ever been, you shivered as the moisture from the saliva made the icy wind leech you of your heat. Wait, why am I wet? You thought to yourself. You lifted your arm and noted the increase in weight, then you realized you were covered head to toe in saliva. You looked up to find both of the giants staring at you concerned. You looked at Thorn, and in response he gave you a familiar gentle smile. Then you remembered.

         You jumped to your feet, “WHAT THE HELL, THORN! WHAT WAS THAT ABOUT?!” you said in exasperation.

         Thorn whined woefully and hung his head low apologetically.

         Bone spoke for him and said, “he did eht to keep ye safe, lad.”

         “Keep me safe?” you parroted.

         “Aye, we were attacked by… wolves. The mutt wasn’t alone.”

         “Oh…” you looked to Thorn, “sorry for freaking out there, it’s just…”

         “Nothin’ needs explaining, lad. We get it. We’re giants, and yer not. I’m sure we’d react the same way if we were ye.” Said Bone.

         You still felt remorse for making the gentlest Smilodon you’ve met so far feel so guilt ridden; he had only tried to protect you after all.

         “I’m happy you did Thorn” you said, to which Thorn’s ears had perked up, “who knows what would’ve happen if you didn’t. Maybe just give me some kind of warning next time” you said as you smiled to Thorn, rubbing the back of your head with your hand.

         Thorn’s sunken posture transitioned back into a high standing and enthusiastic one. He smiled toothily at you.

         [Thank you little one, I apologize once more. I will properly warn you in the future.]

         “No need to apologize. But I do I hope I never need to be properly warned ever again,” you chuckled.

         Bone tilted his head sideways in curiosity, “beg yer pardon, lad?”

         “Oh, nothing” you said, “I was just tellin—” you stopped.

         Then the thought suddenly dawned on you. Who said that?
111131211211111211.title: The mutt is not alone

1111312112111112111.content:
You looked at Thorn’s gentle face but knew that his mouth didn’t move. The context only made sense from his viewpoint, which left you puzzled.

         “Who said that?” you asked.

         “I asked what yer talkin’ about.” said Bone.

         “No, not that. The one that apologized.”

         [That would be me, little one.]

         “There it is again!” you exclaimed.

         It made sense why it was so difficult finding the voice’s owner. It felt so near, yet nowhere close at the same time. The voice almost floated in midair as it spoke to you, you just couldn’t pinpoint where. It was as if two, maybe three people of completely different tones were speaking in unison.

         Bone wrinkled a brow, “thar what is?”

         “The other voice. Can you seriously not hear it?” you asked.

         Bone scanned the surrounding forest for the supposed voice but heard nothing.

         “Just us, lad. Thorn cannae speak, and it wisnae me either” he said.

         You jolted your gaze back and forth between the two giants. Are they playing games with me? The voice didn’t belong to Bone, and as you looked at Thorn’s gentle face, you saw that his mouth didn’t move a muscle.

         “I’m not good with pranks, so cut it out, both of you!” you demanded.

         Bone had concern written on his mug, “ave ye lost it, laddie?”

         [Forgive my friend, little one. For he cannae hear my voice.]

         “Who are you!” you shouted at the woods.

         Bone gave his temple an irritated rub, “Aye, laddie. This some human game, is it?”

         You grind your teeth in frustration. Does he really not hear that?

         [Is it so difficult to tell? We’ve already met, little one] the voice said.

         “Then where are you!”

         [Right in front of you] said the voice.

         You turned to face Thorn once more, and as you stared, your eyes widened in realization. Thorn simply nodded in confirmation, then grinned cheekily.

         [We’ve established a connection, little one. Much sooner than I could’ve anticipated or thought possible. You were particularly receptive to the ability] he said.

         You were gob smacked at the revelation, never in a millennium did you think this would be possible. You had a plethora of questions that needed answering, and now!

         “Something up with Thorn? I nae he ain’t good looking, but…” jested Bone.

         [I ask of you to keep this between us, little one. The others are… not yet ready. But they will be in due time.]

         You scratched your chin as you contemplated the request, “alright, sure” you agreed.

         “Sure what?” Bone asked, noticeably annoyed.

         “Oh. It’s nothing… It’s a… human thing. You wouldn’t get it,” you excused, not sure what else to say.

         [A human thing indeed!] agreed Thorn.

         “Care tell, lad?”

         You wish you were good at lying, the best you came up with was, “We just like… talking… to ourselves… sometimes,” you said as you winced at your lack of improv.

Thorn's eyes squinted in glee, clearly entertained by the exchange.

Bone's brow raised, “…Thar a reason why?”

         “Nope…”

         “So ye just… talk to yerself?”

         “Yep….”

         “Alright…” he finished

         The silence in the forest only became more pronounced thanks to the noise being absorbed by snowfall.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------

         “…Ya lonely, lad?” Bone asked, finally breaking the silence.

         “Not really, now that I got the tribe.”

         “Aye, second that.”

         Bone then burst out with a hearty laugh, “HAH! Ye humans are ah queer bunch! I dinnae get the joke, but good effort, lad!”

         Bone’s smile was genuine this time, completely unlike the detached, sadistic one he’d usually have. You were growing fond of this side of Bone.

         You looked back at Thorn, unsure if you should ask anything right now.

         [All will be revealed in time, little one. But you should know we can communicate without speaking.]

         You could've told me that before I made myself sound like an idiot. How do I even speak to you? You thought.

         [Forgive me, little one,] Thorn snickered, [it was simply too fun seeing ye try to make sense of it.]

         Your perked up in surprise. What?

         [You seem surprised.]

         Does that mean he can hear all my thoughts? You thought, befuddled.

         Thorn shook his head, [neigh, only the ones you’ve allowed me to when ye think of me.]

         This time you formed the thought as a question, [how long have you been able to do this? And when did I allow you?] you asked.

         [It would seem ye pick up this skill very quickly, impressive!]

         [That doesn’t answer my question, when did—]

         [The moment we met, little one. Your eyes told me ye trusted me despite our short introduction, and now you’ve willingly shown the desire to converse with me this way. You’ve given me yer consent.]

         [But I never said anything about consent!] you insisted.

         [Neigh, but your spirit did! Even despite the fear ye felt inside my maw, I felt yer spirit trust me. You do not see me as a threat.]

         [How does any of this even work?] you asked.

         [As I’ve said, in time, little one. However, it’d be wise to continue this conversation later. We’ve made my friend uneasy,] he glanced upwards, indicating Bone.

         You spun your head back to find Bone staring at you, clearly uncomfortable.

         “…Ye lads aight there? Looked like ye two were ‘aving some kind of starin’ match” he teased.

         However, underneath the tease lie genuine worry. He wondered if the human was troubled by something he wasn’t seeing. If the issue were about Thorn, he wasn’t surprised, considering what’d transpired. He knew Thorn was no threat to the tribe; not because he saw him as weak, but because he knew he was disciplined. Thorn would never hurt a fly unless agitated, so most underestimated him despite his incredible but reserved talents. The fact remained though. For all his nurturing temperament, Thorn’s strength was equal to Bone in spite of his size; the only reason he’d not been a higher-ranking member being that he refused the offer. Bone worried that even with his incredible discipline, Thorn may one day hurt the human in ignorance of his strength. He knew Thorn would never intend to do that, but still. If that time ever came, Bone knew he wouldn’t be capable of restraining himself. He knew that he would try to brutally cripple Thorn even if he didn’t want to. He may even unintentionally murder him for such—

         “Yeah, everything’s good” you said, interrupting his train of thought.

         Bone snapped out of his trance of anxieties, “oh, alright then...” he said.

         Though his mind was no longer focused on you two. His attention now was on the sudden and intense feelings he just had. He was stunned by the fact that he would ever think about killing a tribe brother such as Thorn, and all for a human?
1111312112111112111.title: Sudden & intense thoughts

choices: Beat Bone to the chase and meet him afterwards; he's going ahead of him.
Trail behind Bone and help him there; he's going with him.
11113121121111121111.content:
Bone became the odd one out in this situation, the two of recognized he was lost in thought. Something was clearly bothering him, but before you could ask him, Thorn spoke to you.

         [Little one! Remind Bone about the five humans!]

         Five humans? You thought.

         [Yes, five humans! The one the wolves want to sacrifice!]

         Say no more, you thought.

         “Bone!” you called, “we have to go after the wolves, they have our humans!”

         Bone recalled what the wolf said. “Right! We're gettin' them back! Thank ye, laddie.”

         How did ye know about that? Bone thought to himself but brushed it off. There was something more important he needed to consider. He looked down at you sitting on his palm, his brow wrinkled reflectively.

         “What?” you asked.

         “You cannae come.”

         “What, why?”

         “Ya need to go back to camp, laddie, there’s no telling what those wolves might do to ye.”

         “By the time we get back to camp we’re gonna lose their trail!” you said, “we have to go now while there’s still light out! Or—”

         “And if ah lose ye as well?” he interrupted, “what ‘appens if we lose them anyway and I can’t find ya? I wouldn’t be able to save ye before ya froze.”

         “Then who’s gonna save them?!” you pleaded.

         Bone shook his head, realizing you misunderstood him.

         “I am, lad."

         “But… you said—”

         “I said ye cannae come, I never said I wasnae goin’.”

         “I’ll just walk to camp by myself then?” you asked sarcastically.

         “O’ course not, laddie!” he said in reassurance.

         Bone briskly grabbed Thorn’s hand and securely and snugly placed you inside. He gave a stoic expression and lowered his voice in octave.

         “Thorn, ya better take care af him. I’m goin’ after ‘em, ye take him back to camp before nightfall.”

         Thorn nodded, his face completely serious.

         As Bone was about to leave, you shouted, “b-but! Bone! You can’t handle that many by yourself!”

         “HAH! Dun ye worry yerself, lad!” he laughed, “much as I’d like to smash some wolf’s skull in, I dun want to put ar’ humans in danger.”

         “Then how do you plan on getting them back? By asking nicely?” you quipped.

         “I'm goin’ to sneak in, grab ‘em, an’ sneak out” he declared.

         “…A big guy like you? Sneak?”

         He gave a cocky full teeth smile, his thumb pointed towards himself, “aye! Dun forget, I’m a natural born feline! Felines been sneakin’ long before wolves ever walked the land!”

         “But still…”

         “Thas enough af that!” he asserted, “no more arguin’! Thorn, head back now,” he ordered.

         Thorn agreed, gently cupping you with both hands before the two strode off in opposite directions.

         “W-wait! Bone!” you shouted, but he was already long gone by then.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------

You squeezed your head through the crevice between Thorn’s thumbs. He peaked at you as he ran, his ears reddening in a blush, the sight of you like that overwhelming him with your adorable size.

         “Thorn! Do you really think his plan is going to work?” you asked.

         [Do ye not trust your friend, little one?]

         “He’s not my friend!” you stated.

         [Then why are ye so worried?]

         You looked down for a moment and contemplated.

         “Still, I don’t want him to die!”

         Why am I so worried for my captor of all people? You asked yourself.

         [Ye don’t want our humans to die either.]

         “Yeah, but, a big guy like him might kill them on accident! A fall in the wrong place is all it takes!” you said.

         [If I were to go after Bone this instant, he’d kill me for bringing ye along!]

         “Do you really think that oaf can pull it off on his own?” you asked.

         [Of course not.]

         “Then why are you going back to camp?!” you demanded.

         [Little one, when did I ever claim we were going back to camp?]

         What?

         It was then you realized that Thorn had strayed off the path, at some point making a U-turn without your noticing.

         “Wait, where are you going?” you asked.

         He smirked, [Where are we going, little one,] he corrected you.


Where does Thorn plan on going?
11113121121111121111.title: Time to hunt down some wolves

choices: You came shooting into Thorns open palm
You were still inside him, something in the camp changed.
111131211211111211111.content:
It wasn't long before Thorn had caught up with Bone. Hell, you could hear his big fat footsteps in the silent forest air before even seeing him, the brute was made for fighting and not sneaking.

[Typical Bone, Tellin' the whole forest where he is.]
         Thorn thought absently, shooting up a tree while still holding onto you in a hand. You took in a breath as Thorn leaped through the branches, such dexterity and accuracy was unreal as he made his way around Bone and getting out in front of him while in the trees.

[Hopefully I can catch the wolves before they reach their camp, but most likely I won't, night time won't help either as their night vision almost rivals my own.]

         After another few minutes the smell of smoke was in the air and Thorn made a hiss, the first sound you had actually heard from the big cat besides a grunt. He landed on a branch on the outskirts of a clearing, overlooking a camp that was dotted with tents and campfires. Lounging around the area had to be close to a hundred wolves. They were celebrating in a fashion, and centered in the festivities was a dozen smaller wolves that had blood and dirt smeared all over them.

[That must be the survivors of our attackers, Gilron was right, they were initiatives to the pack, youngsters that had no experience.]
         Thorn observed. You couldn't make out as much detail, the Smilodon had you beat in the vision department. He further hammered home his prowess with his sight as he added.

[The alpha male is there, and a human is on his shoulder.]
         He said. You squinted and made out a white wolf that was a head taller than the others. He wore a blood red loincloth that seemed quite ornate and well made. He also had a leather sash going across his bare chest that held a knife and a small pouch, and on his thigh another leather strap fastened a stone hatchet to the large muscle. You couldn't make out no human however.

I don't see him Thorn, or our other humans... You trail off your thought message as thorn used his other hand to tug his loincloth through his briar belt, letting the cloth drape over the branch. You stare dumbfounded at the plump sheath and balls of your companion. As you stared Thorn let out a sigh and his cock slowly emerged from its warm confines into the frigid air. His scrotum drew up slightly now being exposed.

[Take off your pelts] He nudged your mind with the thought and you slightly felt compelled to do just that. You shook your head and thought back.

Why would I do that?? What the hell are you doing Thorn? This is no time for you to be doing this stuff. You say looking at him angrily. Frustration flashes on his face.

[I need both me hands, and don't need ye bein' in the way, trust me when I say I know what I'm doin'. Hurry up this is uncomfortable keeping maself hard in a blizzard.]
         He said and you felt that compulsion flash through your emotions again. Was he doing that? Without another word you slid off Gilrons pelts and stood in the cold air with your teeth chattering. Thorn rotated his palm to where he could pinch you with two fingers and lowered you towards his cock head. This was new, what was he.... Then your feet slipped into his urethra. You gasp and begin to struggle but more fingers secured you.

THORN WHAT ARE YOU DOING!?!? You say in thought and out loud, A finger covered your face and kept most of your cry from spilling out. Thorn hissed again.

[Idiot boy! I said trust me! Yer too powerful for yer own good honestly. Ye didn't take the calm vibes I was sendin' at all. Ye'd be warm inside me and ye will still be able to see.]
         He said as you got up to your waist inside him, he was oozing pre and your own member was hard as a rock as it was enveloped by the much, much larger male. You stop shouting and just watch in terror as the member swallowed you like some snake, it would clench pulling a good portion in before relaxing, only to clench again to claim more of you. Eventually you were up to your neck and all you could do was stare up at Thorn who winked at you before winking his dick and pulling you all the way inside of him.
          A few minutes went by and suddenly you found yourself freefalling a short distance before plunging into a hot liquid. Your first instinct that you had somehow ended up in Thorn's stomach. A quick feeling of the walls told you otherwise. You eyes picked up on the almost nonexistent light that seeped through the membrane of the walls and realized you were in his balls.

[How do ye fair, little one?]
You jerk in response, his voice had always been like a tickle at the back of your mind, but suddenly it rattled throughout your head, and around the walls that surrounded you.

GAH! Why are you so loud suddenly? You send out questioningly.

[Since the outside world is no longer distracting ye, and the fact ye are inside me, ye world essentially is me now. I fill yer thoughts and senses, and control yer fate while like this, we are tied together in this union.]

So what you did this just to get me out of the way?

[Mmm yes and no, but I want ye to try something. Focus on me and think of seeing beyond yer cell, try to see through me.]
Thorn said and the Cell you were in began to wobble as he moved. You focused hard on what he said and after a minute, memories began to play of you running across a branch. You became puzzled, as you didn't have any memories of that, and the vision faded. You tried again and the memory came to you again, only you were in a different tree. It wasn't until memory you took a step and the scrotum shook that you caught on.

AM I SEEING THROUGH YOUR EYES?? You shout in thought and excitement. The memory stopped and a groan rang through Thorn.

[Little one, please refrain from putting so much force behind a thought, ye almost made me fall out of this tree. Yes ye are perceiving through my eyes. I want ye to temper yer thoughts though as ye are much more ingrained in me, you could easily compel me to stumble with yer fear or excitement and that could get me killed. Now, do ye see the human now?]
Thorn said as the memory shifted its sight back towards the camp and focused on the large wolf. Sure enough you made out a human on his shoulder adorned with a pelt that was the same color of his companions coat. He was smiling and laughing at something the Alpha had said.

Oh I see him, and he seems genuinely happy to be with the group that just murdered his protectors.

[Keep in mind little one, we did murder yer rabbit protectors to procure ye, so no deep connections were made, and the rabbits got ye from the wolves through theft, am I correct?] The big cat asked and caught you completely off guard, you didn't know where the other humans were from. They could very well be original members of the Blood Wolves. From the atmosphere, you could tell Thorn honed in on your hesitation, a predator of thought as well as flesh, terrifying.

[If I recall, Bone supposedly took ye from Gilron, am I wrong?]

Uh...no you're not but let's focus on-

[Bone originally opposed having humans, and his rivalry is legendary with the Chief. To suddenly take a human just because it was Chiefs choice made sense but is too shallow an attempt to aggravate Gilron, no you had to be more valuable to Chief for Bone to change his ideology.]

Thorn I don't see why any of this-

[Ye aren't a member of the human tribe we've obtained, are ye? Ye've been a member of Ice Fangs fer' way longer than Bone and Gilron are making it out. Gilron was your guardian and Bone figured that out, so he claimed you in defiance of Gilrons choice to bring the humans in.]
You didn't say anything. Thorn couldn't speak, so that wasn't an issue. But he figured it out and he wasn't there, what happens when the humans confide in their Smilodon companions about what occured in the hut. It could be seen as Bone beating Gilron in cunning and he could lose the Chief spot to Bone. Thorn felt your emotions and continued.

[Those details would've helped from the beginning, this childish bout between those idiots are going to get us all killed. If the humans are from the Blood wolves, it may be futile to try and recover them. We may just have to ask nicely.]
You were brooding until that last part.

Wait what? You mean walk into the wolf camp and ask for them back?

[Precisely]

That could go terribly wrong in more ways than one.

[True, but if the humans I rescue are just bonded with wolves, the wolves will track their scent back to our camp and a raid will ensue. If I die to prevent such a travesty, I'll be content.]

I don't feel so noble, Thorn

[I need to get ye back out to be my speaker. Don't worry they'd probably keep ye, once again, humans are rare around here. Ye could make an addition to their clan or be used as a valuable trading piece.]
The memory of the camp became dark as Thorn began to get you out. A few seconds later and...
111131211211111211111.title: Beat Bone to the chase and meet him afterwards;...

choices: Bone joins in the festivities for a time
1111312112111112111111.content:
With a wet pop you slip out of Thorn and back into his palm. He quickly closed his palms around you and drags you along his thigh, using his fur to dry you off quickly before reaching for a thorn on his belt and removing your pelts where he stuck them to it. He puts them in his palm next to you before cupping his hands closed to keep you warm as you dress. You give him a mental acknowledgement when you were ready and he places you on his shoulder before climbing down the tree. He glances at you as he begins walking straight for the entrance of the camp.

[Ye ready?]

Hell no but I really don't have a choice in this do I?

[Good Point.]

If this didn't work you'd never see your father again most likely. It wasn't long before a bark rang through the camp as Thorn approached, and the festive noise died down. Two wolves stood with spears at the entrance of the camp, but Thorn walked by them with no opposition.

Why didn't they attack?

[Wolves are curious creatures, a Smilodon approaching by himself is obviously not here to fight, I obviously wanna talk, and even if I have nothing to give, they take great interest in other races.] Thorn added.

         You felt eyes and turned to see more than a dozen wolves focused on you solely. Some curious, some hungry, some malicious. You squirmed a little under the gazes. The wolves were roughly the size of Thorn, but a few inches shorter. However among the wolves was an occasional canine that dwarfed the others, their features were sharper and their muscles rivaled Bone's, unlike the leaner builds of their tribe mates. You must've leaked the observation to Thorn as he answered it.

[Dire Wolves, I heard the Blood Wolves had them, but they are exclusively reserved to hunts and Camp defense, They breed slower and their pup mortality is high, so losing one is a great loss to the clan. The fact they have this many however is concerning, not just for us, but the Wolves as well, they must be threatened by something that we don't know about.]

Thorn approached the center fire where the chief was seated near the dozen warriors that had raided your clan. He rose, a Dire himself as he stood as tall as Bone, and addressed Thorn.

         "Hail spirit speaker of the Fangs, I am chief Moonheart. You approach with no weapons, and no other clan members. We respect your position as an ambassador and will not harm you if no harm comes from you. You come during a time of celebration, please join us." He says outstretching his palms and making a wide gesture of peace. Thorn bows his head slightly in acknowledgement. You note the human on Moonheart's shoulder looked worried about the intrusion, and was making expressions as he stared up at Moonheart's face. The wolf wasn't showing any expression, but it was clear they were communicating.

The human is talking to Moonheart. They have a bond.

[Those with an affinity can easily connect with an anthro, that human probably found the wolf attractive and made the connection in some way. It doesn't bode well about the allegiance of the humans, but it doesn't completely throw away our chances. Respond for me, having a staring contest with the Chief doesn't seem wise.]
Thorn said and you stammered out a reply.

         "Uh Thornfur thanks you for the invitation, and agrees to join in your merriment." You say quickly. Moonheart's gaze shifts to you and smiles, but his eyes sent another message.

         "Wonderful, please have a seat and warm yourselves, we celebrate the end of the culling, and the birth of warriors!" He howls and the entire camp erupts with him, sending chills to your very core. The ambiance returns as the wolves go back to celebrating, but its obvious that they were all watching you and Thorn. Thorn sighed and took a seat on a log near the center fire and the Chief soon joined him, sitting on the side of Thorn that you were on. His scent washed over you as he sat down, and you felt extremely exposed being caught between the two predators. The wolf adjusted his loincloth and spoke while looking at the fire.

         "You have quite the stones to walk in here while we celebrate Speaker, what is it that you want." The words were cold, the same as the Wolf's eyes earlier.

[Tell him we want what was taken from us, the humans are our clan.]
You convey that as nicely as you could, Thorn didn't look at the wolf as you did, instead fixing his gaze on the flames as well. The wolf chuckled lightly and looked at you sideways, his eyes catching the fires glint in them.

         "Part of the Ice Fangs? Twigs here told me they were part of the Snowfoot's. That's the rabbits if you were wondering." He said gesturing at the human on his shoulder who was staring daggers at you, he was roughly your age.

[They abandoned them, so we claimed them by right of abandonment. Ye kidnapped them from us.]
You continued conveying to Moonheart.

"I'd say we took them as a reward, humans are rare after all, if you want them back you'll have to make a deal." He said looking past you at Thorn, who was still staring at the fire. It was obvious he knew what you and Thorn were doing.

[What do ye propose?]

"Ice Fangs pack up and leave, get out of this taiga, go south or north, I don't care. You know there isn't enough room for us. The Bears are returning, if one of us is gone, they may pass over the other without a fight."

[We've been in this land longer than ye Blood wolves, it's where our ancestors resided. We won't leave. Maybe an alliance?]

Moonheart scoffed and laughed at that. "Do you speak for your chief or yourself on that Smilodon? I thought you were all about being the strongest, asking for help is beneath you. If you abandon your principles that's worse than abandoning your ancestors lands." He said turning away.

[I'll talk to my Chief, if not an alliance than at least a truce until we get through their passing. Ye seem to know about the potential humans provide. I have to ask, have ye merged?]
You weren't sure what that meant but when you conveyed it Moonheart whipped his head back around and looked dead at Thorn, who turned and looked back at him.

         "I don't know about you Ice Fang's, but that is considered the highest taboo in this clan. Sacrificing your complete solidarity in that way corrupts your soul, and you won't make it to the far lands, but looking at you Speaker of the Fang's, I see you have done such a thing. I'll pray the spirits look past it when your time comes." The wolf said heated, but took a breath and calmed a bit. "I apologize, that was unkind of me. Reach a conclusion with your chief and meet me back here in two nights. I'll return your four humans to you then despite the outcome." He said sighing.

[Five humans]

         Moonheart chuckled. "No...Four, Twigs here has been in the clan since he was five. We were to trade him back from the Snowfoot's after they found him in the forest but you kind of killed that deal. It was luck one of our warriors recovered him in the raid. He, in a sense, is my son, and future chief of the clan." He said smiling fondly at the human. A pang of hurt ran through you as you longed for your own father. The emotion hit Thorn through your connection and a reassuring finger came up and patted your back.

[Interesting that the leader would go from the largest in the clan to the smallest.]

"Not really, he is a master tactician, and knows our lore better than our shamans. He will lead our people to a bright future. In fact the other day he-" Moonheart cut off as a alarm bark ran out suddenly nearby. Moonheart and Thorn stood up and turned around as heavy footsteps sounded from behind to see Bone marching up to him.

[Ah Shite-]
That's all that crossed your mind as Bone slugged Thorn across the face sending him stumbling almost into the fire. Bone's fingers deftly snatched you off Thorn's shoulder and let go of you before sending you spiraling through the air. You crashed into something soft and white and a hand quickly secured you, and you soon realized you had been thrown into Moonheart's chest and he held you now. He glanced down at you in surprise before both you and him looked back at the two cat's.

"I told ye thick headed arse to GO TO CAMP." Bone said slugging Thorn again across the other cheek, stumbling him again. Bone continued. "I didn't mean THIS CAMP!"
         He swung again but Thorn ducked it and delivered a quick jab to Bone's stomach, who grunted and tucked his belly in to avoid most of the impact. Cheers began erupting from the wolves as they cheered on the combatants. Thorn backtracked, avoiding the crushing reach of his larger clanmate, waiting for Bone to miscalculate. You knew Bone wasn't that dim though, he only attacked if he knew he was gonna hit his mark. From here you could see the blood in his eyes, was he really that protective of you already? How long had you been together? Half a day? Movement brought you back to your senses as Thorn moved in suddenly, deftly dodging a fist aimed at his head and slipping past Bone before doing a low sweep kick and knocking Bone on his large ass. The large male grunted as Thorn was suddenly on top of him throwing quick jabs at his face forcing him to put his hands up to protect himself. Bone pulled up a powerful leg and caught Thorn under the chin, slinging him down onto the dirt and pinning him with his calf. Bone sat up and quickly put his hands around Thorns throat, choking the Shaman out in a few seconds. Bone released the grip before it turned fatal and sat back panting. The crowd went silent with awe.

         "Dunno why he thought he hadda' chance." Bone said getting to his feet and pointing at Moonheart. "I'll be takin' that back now. You got any firewater?" The wolves cheered and began clapping backs as Bone propped Thorn up against the log and took you back from the Wolf Chief and a skin of firewater from a passing wolf, chugging its contents and letting it stream down his face before sighing...

11113121121111121111111.content:
"Welcome...Aggressive one, to our celebration, please enjoy yourself, just don't do what you did to any of my brethren and we will get along fine." Moonheart said skeptically as Bone threw the waterskin to the sighed and belched. He grunted in acknowledgement and nodded at the skin.

         "Thanks, what's that stuff, I can feel it already. My tips are all tingly." He said as he placed you on his shoulder, you were focused in concern on the unconscious Thorn.

         "We've been taking to calling it 'moonshine', due to it being clear like the shine of our guide at night. We make it from Maize, so during winter we can't make it unless we take it from our stores. If your friend there succeeds in his mission, I'd be happy to share how we make it." Moonheart says with the smile that was obviously fake. Bone grunted again.

         "And what mission would thatta be?" Bone asked, and Moonheart explained all that they had covered. When the Wolf finished Bone spat to the side.

         "What gets me is that ye 'ad peace talks with a damn mute. How tha hell did ye get all that from 'im" He said jutting a chin at the prone cat. You paled, that didn't even cross your mind. Moonheart caught on that the Ice Fangs didn't know about the stuff of humans and saved the day.

         "He drew in the snow and the human on your shoulder helped translate, it was quite easy actually." Moonheart stated.

"Riiiight, aight then.." Bone said grabbing two more skins off a hook nearby and sliding down to the ground, using the log as a backrest. He tossed one skin onto Thorns chest and began chugging his own. Moonheart gave his fake smile before departing, joining in with a nearby group of wolves and leaving Bone alone with you. The sun was almost gone , a pink and orange glow all that was left in the sky to the west. Above the aurora danced slowly across the sky, lore stated it was the collection of the spirits that had perished on this day departing for the Far Lands, Bone watched it move and sighed.

         "Greenfoot is up there somewhere, hope he enjoys the endless warmth the Far Lands provide, along wit' tha bountiful prey." He said taking another swig, his gulping loud as you watched his throat expand as he took in the liquid.From here you couldn't help but observe the physique again of Bone. His enormous chest heaved and fell, his breasts swelled with power, the space between them deep and inviting, you longed for the cleft between your fathers pecs, where you spent many a cold night within. Beyond his chest was a landscape of white fur, with hills rising underneath it that marked his abs clearly, forming tiny valleys between them. Beyond was the blood stained cloth that covered a mound that you had been up close and personal with already, but you longed to visit again soon as well. It rested between his tree trunk thighs as he idly rocked his legs back and forth, setting the bulge to wobbling. Without a word, and while he was watching the sky, you slid down across his chest, the flesh giving slightly at your weight as you made your way to the cleft. As you slid in he became aware of your intrusion and his pecs tensed up and squeezed you. It hurt a good bit but he quickly realized it was you and relented.

"What are ye doin' lad?" He said as he looked down on you. You wriggled a little deeper before replying.

"Getting comfy."

"Tha's comfy?"

"Extremely."

"Did Gilron always put ye there?"

"Every night, his heartbeat put me to sleep, letting me know something that powerful would keep me safe through the night." You say slipping even further in, no doubt about it, Bone's cleft was twice as deep, you could probably slip completely in without being seen from the outside, but that also meant you could get completely crushed. Bone relaxed and you slipped up to your neck in his chest before he let his chest close slightly, pulling you into a warm embrace. His heart beat drummed below, pulsing through your body and calming you.

         "Yet makin' me feel guilty lad, I stole ye from yer old man. I can't go back on what I did, and I can't replace 'im, but I can be there for ye. Get some rest, we got a long walk in the mornin'."

"What about you?" you ask as he took another swig. He belched loudly before responding.

"Imma stay up, don' trust these pups, they killed Greenfoot and 'ere I am among em, and Thorn may try to attack me when he comes 'round. Sleep tight laddie."
He says looking up at the fire. You close your eyes and focus on the heartbeat. And before you knew it the troubles of today were giving way to another tomorrow....
