111131211211111211111111.content:
Before long light and a loud rumbling awoke you. Bleary eyed you sat up, popping up between the large mounds that were Bones pecs. The big snored loudly, causing his chest to vibrate and jiggle from the strength of it. How you slept at all through this was a mystery. You blink as sunlight streams into you face over the tree tops and observe the sights around you. The bonfire had died down to embers and crackled weakly, and beyond it a dozen or so wolves lat sprawled over one another in different forms of rest. Some blatantly snored like Bone while others blinked their droopy eyes, fighting off the aches of a hangover. A couple wolves were up and moving around, beginning their chores for the day. Nearby Moonheart ate what seemed to be somethings cooked leg, tearing off a piece and handing it to Twigs on his shoulder. The Chief probably didn't leave the Smilodons unattended during the night. You look to your left and see Thorn propped up no more than a foot away from Bone looking at the dying fire.

         "Oh Thorn! You're awake!" You say excitedly. The mute Shaman looked at you and smiled, but no voice rang in your head. "Did you say something? I couldn't hear you." You say and Thorn frowned before putting a hand on his forehead.

         "He was knocked unconcious, the bond was severed, you need to reestablish it." Moonheart said without looking in your direction. You glance at him and then back at Thorn, who nodded in agreement with the wolf. Moonheart continued. "Sleeping or lack of full consciousness will sever all but the strongest bonds. If you were to knock me out, Twigs would still be connected to me. Hell, our bond is strong enough to where I had full contact with him throughout him being in your custody, thats how the culling found your group." You frowned at that.

         "You sent the new guys to save your son?" You scoffed at the Chief, who smiled.

         "Noooo.....I sent the new guys to distract you while my Dires isolate and kill the cat that had my Twigs." He said reaching up and patting Twigs on the head. You were a little agitated about that.

         "Why not just negotiate like Thorn here did, why kill one of ours?" You say. Moonheart laughed.

         "Tell me, was your first plan to get your humans back talking about it? I bet that big fellow you're on fully intended full blown war. That face you made tells me I'm right. You seem to be the only human that understands your actual value, and Thorn there seems to be the only Ice Fang that realizes that too. Your big guy may not realize it, but violence is the best way to get your humans back. The only reason I offer your's back in this fashion is because it may be the only guarantee to survive the White Winds." Moonheart said tossing the bone of his meal into the dying fire.

         "White Winds?"

         "The Polar Bear tribe, big brutes larger than your snoring friend there, I've seen one rip a dire wolf in half with his raw strength. And they're smart, they can sneak right up on a camp and destroy it in seconds." Moonheart said, idly groping at a scar that he had on his stomach. You pause and think for a moment.

         "You said Twigs was on Greenfoot, but we found Greenfoot's human dead with him." You ask. "How is that?"

         "During the scuffle, the human panicked and tried to attack Twigs, my son took some string from the sack he was in and strangled the man with it. Shame really but it had to be done." Moonheart said taking out a knife and beginning to sharpen it. "It had come down to that man and Twigs, all the other humans had been picked, Twigs thought he could get stuck with your Chief so we could get two birds with one stone, but your Chief told this Greenfoot fella' to take both of them." The wolf noted. You clench your teeth, anger at the human on the Wolf's shoulder boiled over. That little shit had tried to get your father killed, and only because he had lost you and didn't want to replace you did he survive. You took a deep breath and glanced at Thorn, the cat opened his mouth and pointed a finger into it. Seemed he wanted to reestablish the bond so you nodded your head. As he began to reach for you however a large hand shot up and gripped Thorn's wrist, making him jerk in surprise. A growl rumbled beneath you as Bone sat up, teeth bared at the smaller cat. A few wolves that were lounging nearby perked up at the sound and watched closely, wanting to see if it'd evolve into another scuffle. Bone spoke through clenched teeth.

         "Ye keep yer damn paws off of 'im, he's not leavin' me side again, understand?" This time was different, instead of it being an intent to brawl, Bone held the intent to kill, and Thorn knew that. The mute tiger remained calm and stared into Bone's eyes, before looking elsewhere, a sign of resignation. Bone let go of his arm and sat up, you still squished between his pecs. Moonheart eyed the big cat wearily.

         "You sir, are the reason I may have to reconsider my proposal with the speaker there. You lot are too aggressive and pugnacious." He said moving Twigs to his other shoulder, so that his body was between him and Bone. Bone spat and looked sideways at the white canine.

         "Dunno 'bout that lad, 'ave ye seen yer men out there? Not much different cept' we Cats don't sniff each others asses." Bone said stretching. "Don' judge yer choice on me alone, in a sense, I'm not one of these kittens." Your protector stood up and pulled you from his chest and set you on his shoulder. Moonheart seemed unamused at the comment.

         "We will see, now if you don't mind I'd say you overstayed your welcome, you'd best be off before my boys come around and remember you killed their sons yesterday." Moonheart said standing up and gesturing Bone and Thorn to follow. You all walked through the camp and exited on the north side. Moonheart stopped at the end of the clearing, Pine trees casting you in cold morning shadow as the wold turned to Thorn.

         "I await your return in two nights, Spirit Speaker, if I don't here from you, the humans remain with us." Moonheart said, giving a shallow bow to Thornfur, who returned the gesture. With a wave the wolf chief marched back into his camp, Twigs on his shoulder glaring at you. Bone snorted.

         "As if we'd make a treaty with these bitches, ay Thorn?" Bone said turning and facing the shorter cat, who just glared at him before walking off and beginning his way home. Your protector grumbled out of the side of his mouth at you. "What's with 'im Lad?" You look at him in disbelief.

         "You did just threaten him for just reaching for me."

         "I did?"

         "Yeah you did, everyone felt the murderous intent you held."

         "Ah Shite....Thorn I didn' mean that!" Bone said as he trotted after the Shaman, you holding on as he carelessly bounded through snow drifts.....

1111312112111112111111112.content:

No one spoke the whole time, you had tried to strike up conversation with Bone once, but he shushed you. Thorn walked ahead of you two, stopping occasionally as his ears twitched and listened to sounds that you couldn't detect. You sigh and lounge against Bone's neck, the big cat paid you little mind, his body tense as he marched after his smaller clan mate. Why the were so uptight was beyond you sin-. Then the arrow cut across Bone's shoulder where you had been moments before, a string of blood came out of the gash as it flew onward towards Thorn. The mute tiger dropped to the ground as the arrow embedded itself in a tree a few feet ahead as Bone hissed and dove behind a fallen log nearby. Blood poured and steamed on his shoulder, filling your senses with its metallic smell. You panic and take off your chest pelt, blotching at the wound trying to stop the bleeding covering yourself in his blood in the process.

         "Damn it lad I'm fine, it's not as bad as it looks." He said pulling you off his shoulder and noting you dripping in his life water. "Ah shite now yer gonna get the cold death soon if i don't clean ye" Bone noted as he pivoted and looked over the log. You looked around for Thorn but he was nowhere to be seen, there weren't even footprints in the snow to hint where he had gone.

         "I don't see anything." Bone whispered, pulling some moss off the log and pressing it into his shoulder, a curse slipped through his lips as he ducked and another arrow nicked the tip of his ear and sailed on through the Forest. "Alrighty now I see 'em, Elk archers, four of them...Shite."

         "Is that bad?" You ask slightly panicked.

         "Considerin' they got the best aim in these lands and the big bulls are roughly as strong as me, yes its a problem." Bone sighed. "The wolves have been fightin em' for decades, they probably don' like the sight of two Sabers walkin' out of the dog camp, that stinks of alliance. I needya to peek for me laddie."

         "What? but what if they shoot me? I can't take arrows like you!"

         "Yeah yeah but if just yer thick head goes over the log I doubt they can do much damage." He says as he lets you grip the bark and climb up it. You slowly peek you head over the wood and don't make anything out. The forest was way too quiet for this to be a fight right now. it wan't until what you had mistaken for low tree branches moved that you finally noted the first elk, He was pressed against a tree and was roughly the same shade of it. He was tall, as tall as Bone, and his antlers stood another two feet past his head. He wore a harness that secured a quiver on his back, and a bow was drawn and pointed directly at you, though you don't think he made you out at that distance. His breechcloth fluttered in the breeze, what appeared to be wolf teeth decorated its frontal shawl and a saber tooth knife hung from the belt. Movement to your right made you see two more of the Elk moving away, looking up in trees and following swiftly and quietly. You did not, see the fourth one. You quickly relay what you were seeing.

         "Thorn must be splitting them up for me, and no fourth which means-" As he said that feet crashed down near you as the fourth elk suddenly was standing on the log with you underneath him. He had two hatchets in his hands as he stared down at the nicked Tiger. The bull elk let out a huff of air, it coming out of his nostrils in a billowing steam cloud before he bellowed and leaped down onto Bone. The cat snarled as he rolled out of the way as a hatchet sank into the snow where his head had just been. Bone swept his leg out from under the Elk and jumped on top of his prone form, rolling back and forth as you watched with tense fear as your protector struggled against the foe, something you hadn't seen out of Bone before. Your fear went to horror as the other Elk stepped from a tree nearby, bow drawn and aimed at the side of the big cats head. You panic, you were about to see Bone get killed and there was nothing you could do! You stared hatefully at the Elk as he drew back his arrow. You closed your eyes and drew in a breath, you couldn't watch Bone die. When you opened your eyes however the most peculiar thing happened.
         You weren't standing where you had been before, no, you were standing off to the side with a bow in hand aiming it at the tussling anthros. You were big! You undraw the bow and look down, and gasp. You were in the Elk, it was similar to when you were seeing through Thorn's eyes, but more clearly. When you moved your limbs, the Elks limbs moved, the power behind them was immense compared to what you were used too. You glanced at the log and saw a small figure covered in blood lying prone on it, was that you? A voice came ringing in your head from somewhere, it was loud and had a musical note to it.

         WHAT THE HELL? WHY CAN'T I MOVE MYSELF? The voice rang.
You ignored it and focused back on the fight going on in front of you. The Elk rolled on top of Bone and drew back the hatchet behind his head. With a grace that was not your own, you drew the bow quickly and let the arrow fly, it cut through the right eye of the other Elk and soared out the back of his head. His body stayed upright for a second before seizing once and toppling over. Bone rolled and sputtered, before freezing in a crouched position as he locked eyes with you. That murderous intent you had felt from him before bore into you and made every hair on this new body stand on end. The voice from before came back.
          I KILLED OAKHORN?! MOVE BODY! WHY WON'T YOU RESPOND TO ME? The limbs began to move for another arrow, you were losing your control of the Elk body. You spoke quickly through alien lips.

         "Bone it's me I-" You didn't see him grab the hatchet, you only knew he had because it had suddenly ended up in the Elks chest after a quick flick of his arm. Scarlet blood seeped out around the axe head and you coughed before falling back into the snow. Words couldn't escape you as searing pain took over all senses, the voice in the back of the mind became stronger as it cried in pain, its anguish shoving you from consciousness.
         After a moment you gasped back awake and clutched at your chest, only to find no hatchet there, you sat up, the ghost of the pain still fresh as you quickly realize you were back in your own body. You look up to see Bone picking up the other hatchet and walking over to the prone form of the Elk, who weakly crawled backwards away from the big cat. Bone put a foot on his chest and swiftly brought the axe down on the bull elks's throat, silencing the raggedy breaths that the cervine took. Bone threw the weapon aside and looked at you with raised eyebrows.

         "Well lad, I've been in many fights, but I've never seen someone fuck up a two versus one that bad. The bloody idiot shot his own clan mate through the noggin'." Bone laughed, his adrenaline still high, but he noticed you being quiet and looking quite sickly. He walked over and crouched down. "Ye got the look of someone who tasted death, is it really that cold out here to ye?" He said sympathetically.

         "N-no, well...yes, but it's not that. For a moment...I took over that elk with the bow.....I....killed someone." You say rocking back and forth slightly. The reality of all that transpired in that past few seconds sinking in. Bone stared at you with a look you reserve for a crazy person.

         "Mmmm no laddie I'm pretty sure ye just sat there lookin' cute and clueless." He said chuckling slightly but letting it die off when you didn't give him a look or respond. A crunch of snow sounded and Thorn landed nearby, dropping out of a tree. He surveyed the situation, pausing on the body with the arrow hole in the eyesocket. Thorn looked at Bone and rose an eyebrow. Bone sniffed.

         "Bowman over there shot his bud through the 'bulls eye' there, heh, then just stood there and smiled at me like we were besties. Laddie here is claiming he was the bull, and I claim he's completely crazy. Put an axe in his chest before finishin' the job, and find this fella rockin' back in forth." Bone said grabbing more moss and dabbing his shoulder. Thorn looked between the bodies, and then back at you with a look of pure fascination and horror on his face. He looked at Bone and frowned, he obviously wanted to establish that mental bond like before, but knew he'd have to fight Bone to do it. The smaller cat got Bone's attention and said nothing as usual but made very subtle gestures before loking back at you. Bone followed his gaze.

         "Oh right he wasted his pelts trying to stanch me cut. Alright laddie lets get you cleaned up and warm." He said plucking you up. You were rolled into his hand and the moment you were on your feet a huge pink organ crashed into you as Bone was giving you a tongue bath. He passed over you before pulling back and plastering you with his tongue and pulling you into his mouth. The place stunk of firewater and spoiled meat, but you couldn't deny the warmth it provided. Bone tossed you slowly through his expansive mouth. His large fangs and teeth not bothering you the slightest as you closed your eyes and just enjoyed the heat. Eventually he spat you back out and looked down at you before showing you to Thorn.

         "There squeaky clean mama hen, now can we get moving? Don' wanna get attacked by more, doubt they'll kill each other for me again." Bone said. Thorn looked at you again somberly, before turning to go. Bone suddenly decided that his shoulder would be too cold and slipped you...

As Bone got lost in pleasure, Pup was taken up in the act as well.

...

The skin pulled away to reveal a queer sight that took a moment to process. Bone had made his sheath retreat, leaving it wrapped around your waist as you stared down the valley that was his thighs. Between the Thighs was the torso of Thorn, his body leading up to his mouth that slid down Bones length, only inches above you. You just stared in disbelief up at the cats getting it on. Back in the water, you could make out that Thorn was fully erect as well, clearly enjoying this as well. A loud slurp and squelch sounded above as the lips parted for a moment and Thorns tongue snaked down Bones length, passing over you and plastering you to Bone. The muscle slipped into the folds of the sheath, scooping up your legs and pulling you quickly up into his mouth, dragging you back and forth along the large member. You sputtered as you were tossed around, Thorn going up and down on Bone, getting highly invested in the intercourse. After a time you ended up near the back of the mouth, Bones dick head above you, the glans swelling and pulsing from the extreme stimulation. You gripped at it for dear life, suddenly being thrust over the chasm that was Thorns throat. You let out a cry at the sight and the atmosphere changed as a voice rang in your head.

Little one, can you hear me? The musical voice that was Thorn rang in your thoughts over the sound of blood pumping.

"Thorn? You're about to eat me! Get me out now!" You say in your head and out loud as Bone thrusts again, dragging you completely over. In desperation you gripped the phallus, sinking your hands into Bones slit as he obviously was reaching climax.

Let go little one, no need for you to get crushed by being rammed into the back of my throat He said casually. Bone pulled back, dragging you across the back of Thorns tongue, the muscle attempting to dislodge you from Bone.

"As much as being swallowed sounds great, I'd like to pass on that Thorn." You say as another thrust pulled you over the undulating throat, the muscles unconsciously awaiting your descent. Thorn growled slightly.

The bond is reestablished, hurry and fall so I can finish him off and we can talk. He said like he wasn't asking you to literally be food.

"If you don't get me out, I'm gonna make sure I give you the shits!" You say as you let go, screaming as you plummet down the throat, the muscles squeezed you eagerly, coating you in mucus as you descended. With a quick squeeze you popped into a dim cavity that was Thorns stomach.

....

Bone pulled his head back and yowled, not the best thing to do when you were surrounded by enemies, but at this moment he didn't care. Thorn kept a consistency, teasing Bone by keeping him on the edge, prolonging his climax as he worked his head. Suddenly a weight lifted from Thorns tip, but as soon as it did, Thorn changed his tactic, pulling back while sucking, then coming back down hard. 11113121121111121111111121.title: In the front of his breechcloth

111131211211111211111111212.content:
As you sit there trying to recover from what transpired, the universe decided it didn't want to give you the time to do so. An arrow grazed across Bone's thigh, drawing a hiss out of the big cat who shot up and dove into the pool, still oblivious to you as you're thrown into the air. Thorn catches you and you look back in the dim dusklight to see half a dozen Elk standing on the wood edge, bows drawn as they advanced. Thorn let out a gasp at the sight and swam to the other side of the pool, arrows whistling by and splashing in the water. Bone emerged near where he dove in, reaching and grabbing his breechcloth and Thorns briar belt before following, leaving the bow and arrows behind.. Both cats jumped out of the pool and sprinted for the treeline opposite of the Elk, only for more to emerge from the trees in front of the Smilodons.
         Bone rushed one, sliding under a shot directed at his eye, and came up throwing his breechcloth around the confused Elk, Bone grabbed the ends of it as he passed the Bull and crouched as he pulled hard. The elk fell back, the back of his neck landing on Bone's shoulder. Bone pulled hard and an audible crack rang out as the Elks neck broke. The large cat pulled free and continued his retreat with Thorn. He glanced at the smaller male and saw you in a cupped hand as he ran, furrowing his brow and looking at his bouncing junk but not saying anything.
         An Elk's bugle call rang out, and others answered it all around within the forest, filling the air with a eerie song.

         "Shite, their all aroun' us Thorn. I can't kill 30 Bull Elks with a length of cloth." Bone griped.

          Thorn looked around and pointed, and both you and Bone followed his finger. Bone completely went pale as a dreamcatcher hung in a branch about 9 feet up. The edges of it were lined with dense white fur. Bone growled fiercely.

         "Polar Bears? POLAR BEARS THORN??? Ye wan' us to try an' seek refuge with those monsters? Yeah no thank's Lad. I'll take an arrow before I go to the Polar Bears for help." Bone said crossing his arms.

         As if on cue, a meaty thunk sounded as an arrow dug into Bone's shoulder and the cat snarled in pain and whirled around to see three Elk closing in. You gasp at the sight of the shaft sticking out of Bone's strong shoulder. This whole time he had seemed invincible but now rivets of blood flowed down the lines between his muscles. Thorn grabbed Bone's good shoulder and tugged it telling him it was time to go, and Bone relented. Thorn quickly snapped the shaft so it wouldn't get in the way and they mad their way until the forest made way for snow covered tundra. After about ten minutes of running Bone made a slurred remark.

         "Thuuurn? I tink tha' arro was poisonnned." He said beginning to stumble. Thorn looked at him then down at you.

         I need you to merge with him, but stay to the side and control his breathing and heart rate. I can see the polar bear village, but also the Elk behind us, we can't afford a minutes rest. Thorn said glancing back and forth.

         But I don't even know how I did it earlier Thorn, I'm at a loss here. You say glancing at the faltering Bone.

         Focus on Bone, pool your desire to be with him, and it'll be so. Thorn said as he turned back to focus on running.

         You looked at your protector, barely being able to keep himself on his feet, and focused on him and closed your eyes, reaching out with mentality and spirit. When you opened your eyes they were not your own, but rather ones that had a dark tint along the edges, pain rang from your shoulder and chest. Something felt as though it crept through your veins, and Bone's voice boomed throughout.

         Just gotta put one foot after the other.....Just gotta put one foot after the other.... His mind repeated this as he slowed down. You spoke to him.

         Bone? It's me, I'm gonna take over breathing alright? Just focus on running. You say as you somehow take over breathing, though you have no idea how you're doing it, it just happens. Bone replied hazily.

         Pup? What are ye doin' in me head? You're suppose' to be over there. His gaze drifted to your limp body in Thorns hand. WHAT DID THAT BASTARD DO TO YE? Anger flowed throughout and you almost drowned in it.

         Nothing! He did nothing Bone, this is my doing, I'll be fine, but only if you focus on running and not on me. You said and the anger boiled away a good bit.

         Okay then, focus on runnin'... His mind slipped and incoherent thoughts filled the space.
         Ahead was the village, a bunch of igloo's with smoke pouring from them into the night sky. An Elk bugle sounded behind you as if they were calling the chase off, obviously walking into a village of unknown numbers would be foolish, especially if the village was filled with the legendary monsters that were the polar bears.
         The enormous body of Bone faltered and despite you quickly trying to take the reins you faceplanted in the snow. Thorn stopped and sounded like he returned and lifted up Bone a bit and looked you in the eyes. You however couldn't hear him as you realized you were now in a bond with Bone. Thorn pointed a hurried finger from Bone to your limp body, obviously telling you to return to your own. You obliged but as you departed everything went dark....

....

         You gasp and sit up, looking around aimlessly. You were in a dim, circular room with a small fire crackling in a pit in the center. The floor beneath you rose and fell and looking around you saw that you were on Bones belly, fur scraps bundled around you in a sort of sleeping bag. Bone himself was nude and exposed, his shoulder and thigh bound with grass and mud, a minty scent drifted from the dressings. Thorn wasn't anywhere to be seen.

         "The Spirit speaker seemed adamant to leave you on the Giant Claw, he said that you needed to find your way back, and it seems you did, two days later." A deep voice said.
         You whirled to see an enormous figure step from the shadows and loom over you. A Polar Bear. He was as muscular as Bone and a good few inches taller. He crouched down, a Breechcloth made of hide covered his sensitive bits.

         "You humans irritate me, working your ways into societies, and when your value is revealed, war happens. The only reason you are on the Giant Claws belly and not inside mine is because we are observing the Spirit Speakers request of harmony." The Bear said with a monotone voice. You look at him with fear and skepticism.

         "I didn't choose to be a human, I didn't ask to be alive. You can't blame me for simply being." You say to the monster.

         "No, but you can choose to die, and you haven't yet, and I hate you for it." He said getting into a sitting position and placing a hand over Bones chest, feeling the heartbeat. "Your friend here will heal in time, Elk are naturalist when it comes to poison, but we are naturalist purifiers, that includes purifying the world of your kind." He said, leaving his hand on Bone, a challenge in a way.

         "Why should I die? What have I done to wrong you?" You say looking up at the bears face. He had Ice blue eyes that burned through your soul, and you squirmed under such a colossal beings gaze.

         "Your abilities, your...psionics. It's unnatural, and many a species have vanished to the far lands due to wars fought for your kind. From what I've seen, you are a powerful one, and my gut longs to purge you from this world, but alas, laws of harmony leave you sitting here insulting me with your existence." He said licking his lips, and a shiver ran down your back.

         "Where's Thorn?" You ask.

         "The silent speaker left you in our care, he wrote that he needed to spread the chance of a peace between his clan and the wolves to stop the bears." He said

         "And you let him go? Aren't you...you know? The bears...." You say looking him up and down. The monster peeled back the mud on Bone's thigh, and a foul smelling substance was plastered to it and around an angry cut, the bear put the wrap back on.

         "Typical human, completely devoid of any idea of what is going on. No, we are not 'the bears', the ones other tribes refer to are our Brothers who had sided with humans, and now they walk the earth as mindless vagrants beg for nothing but blood and pillaging. They are the pinnacle of what my culture preaches. That is; Purge humans, don't protect them. My gut hungers for you the more you keep flapping your lips." He said before bending down and kissing Bone on the lips. "The fact you now are with my old friend makes this all the worse."

         "You knew Bone Snapper?" You ask incredulously. And the bears eyes turned a somber note.

         "Bone Snapper now is it, huh Atanik?" The bear said smiling down at the sleeping cat. "Yes I knew 'Bone' here, he grew up in this area, our clans were close allies, but he blames us for the destruction of his clan since it was the Vagrant bears, and in turn I blame humans." His original demeanor returned and he looked at you.

         "My name is Kilak, in your tongue it simply means Sky, and Atanik here means 'leader', as he was destined to be so of his people." The bear said standing up. "I'm fetching water, do you need food human?" He said it with kindness, but his pure hatred for you stayed in his eyes.
         You nodded your head and he departed, leaving you in the igloo alone with Bone...
111131211211111211111111212.title: An arrow flies by, you've been found!

1111312112111112111111112121.content:
Bone jerked awake.

         “PUP!” he shouted.

         His gaze darted across the unfamiliar shelter, he knew danger wasn’t present, but Pup was nowhere to be found. Then he felt squirming underneath his ribs, finding you pinched between the fold of his abs and lower chest. With a sigh of relief, his panic subsided. He plucked you out and placed you on his palm, coddling your warmth and stroking your head with the back of his white claw. His smile was genuine like the one in the forest.

         “Phew, thank the ancestor.” he said

         " 'Pup?' ” you asked.

         He blinked, “that’s right, I hadn’t told ye.”

         “So 'Pup' meant me?”

         “Aye.”

         “Why ‘Pup?’ I mean, we’re not wolves or something, and I'm not that young.”

         He shook his head, “neigh, laddie, ‘Pup’ as in ‘Puppet’. “

         “I mean— I don’t think I’m a puppet.”

         He tapped his forehead, “I know that ye wee monkey, not when yer tha puppeteer.”

         “Ohhh,” you said.

         Truth be told, you had no idea what he was talking about. Puppeteer? Then it hit you. As soon as it did you tried flushing it out. The surrealism of it all was a living nightmare, it was too real for you to accept. You felt the dull blade of the axe lodge into your chest, or the Elk’s chest. You were burned by the hot blood painting you in the biting cold. Then to have it clot in your throat— It was agonizing. However, not in part due to pain, but because you were living the fear of the Elk as he huffed his last breathes. The thought of being the cause of that pain, living that pain, then accepting that pain… No, you never wanted to experience that again. What if that were me? What if I died there? You shivered and shook your head. Enough.

         “Ye dun like it?”

         You snapped out of it.

         “No, no, of course I like it!” you said exposing your palms.

         “Yer not just saying that ar ye?”

         “If it bugged me, believe me, you’d be the first to know” you smirked, rubbing an eye with your finger.

         “HAH! Cheeky lil shite! Aye, ‘Pup’ it is!”

         “Pup and Bone,” you said scratching your chin, “not a bad duo!”

         “Neigh! It’s Bone and Pup!”

         “Why does your name come first?”

         “Cause I can swallow you whole, laddie”

         You snapped and pointed a finger, “good point,” you said.
1111312112111112111111112121.title: Pup & Bone

choices: Kilak's son, who's your age, enters the tent.
11113121121111121111111121211.content:
The two of you smiled at each other. Bone attempted to stand but the pain made him drop back down. With a hand on his leg, he felt his blood seep through the wrappings.

         “ERGH! Thas gonna leave a hackit ol’ scar,” he said with the slightest bit of delight, “another to tha’ collection, aye?”

         Though you’ve noticed, you never thought to bring it up. There were three slashes across his muzzle, and more lining his neck to chest. Most of his right ear appeared as if it had been ripped off. Needless to say, he’d obviously seen action in his time. One scar in particularly stood out to you. On his abdomen was an area of discolored skin that looked as if it sunk inwards, being closer to a burn than a scar. It was not a light burn either, whatever had happened must’ve been incredibly painful.

         “How’d you get that one?” you asked.

         “Which?”

         You pointed, “the one on your abs.”

         You thought Bone would relish the opportunity to gloat, instead he froze and stared vacantly into nothing. He was entranced in thought again.

         “That one… Let’s neigh talk ‘bout that one, laddie,” he said in a subdued tone as his clutched the area.”

         “Looked like it hurt.”

         “...In a lot mor’ ways than one.”

         “So, how’d you get it?”

         He shut his eyes, “That es for anotha’ time— Not today.”

         Bone surprised you when he was like this. You’d expect someone like him to get aggressive if something bothered him, you never expected him to become somber and quiet. It frustrated you, it meant there was never a simple approach with these giants. Then again, you should’ve known this by now, since these things haven’t really been clear cut when you left your father.

         You smirked, “a big cat, scared of old wounds? I’m sure I’ve seen you go through worse in the short time we’ve known each other, you gonna let this one get you down?”

         He shook his head meekly, “ye ‘ave no idea what 'worse' is, boy— Les’ keep it that way."

         “You don’t trust me?

         “Nutin’ to do wit trust, it’s… hard to relive.”

         “When has it never been hard for us? We’re cats.”

         His ears perked at calling yourself a "cat," but he didn’t press it further.

         “Ah know that, lad— I know ah may look big an’ strong to you, but—"

         “You are big and strong! I’d expect you to brag about your scars, not whimper about them!

         He scratched his head and gritted his teeth. “Enough, thes is nutin’ to be proud of.”

         “You can’t honestly be this much of a chicken!”

         “AH SAID ENOUGH!” the large cat roared, bearing his massive fangs, but his eyes watering with solemnness.
It caught you off guard to say the least. Was what you said really enough to make him almost cry? Still, his roar made you recoil and lose composure.

         “Shall I swallow him for you?” the familiar voice spoke, “this one seems far nosier than a human should ever dare to be.”

         Kilak stood at the doorway fold of the white tent, a wooden board of meats in hand. His voice was gentle, barely a whisper, but his eyes shot you with burning fury.

         Bone jolted up the seat, grabbing you firmly and shielding you behind his body. A quick glance around the tent and he grabbed the nearest object in sight.

         “BACK OFF YE FUCKIN’ SNOW COATED SHITE!” he said as he chucked a ceramic bowl with what little strength he could muster.

         The contents of the bowl sprayed the room, but the bowl landed safely on the white bear’s massive palm as he caught it without flinching.

         “ ‘Snow coated shite’ now, is it? You wound me, Atanik.”

         Bone’s eyes narrowed as he stiffened, his tail puffing twice it’s size. “HOW DO YE KNOW THAT NAME?!”

         The bears eye’s furrowed, “have you forgotten your own kin, Atanik?

         Bone looked as if realization slapped him across the face, he scrunched his snout in anger, but pointed his gaze to the floor.

         “As if ah would ever be kin wit a milk colored inbred.”

         Kilak clenched his jaw but brushed the insult off. “Atanik—”

         “YE ‘AVE NO RIGHT TO CALL MEH THAT!”

         “What else would I call you, my kin?”

         “…Bone Snapper— And I AM NOT YOUR KIN,” he pointed.

         Kilak breathed in heavily though his large black nose, “fine, ‘Bone Snapper,’ do you honestly blame us for what happened—”

         “YES!” bone interrupted.

         “Even though we tried protecting your tribe?”

         “…Ye snow leeches are tha’ same, ye never protected us, ye just used us!"

         Kilak folded his arms, “surely now? So keen on using you that we shared our crops, our hunt, and sheltered you all?

         Bone guffawed, “HAH! Who was harvesting thos’ crops? Who hunted meat for tha’ pack of ya?”

         “You know very well that we sent as many healthy as we could to assist, my friend. How can you deny tha—"

         Bone slammed his fist on a table, “AH AM NOT YER FRIEND EITHER! AND YE SURE AS ‘ELL COULDA’ SENT MORE IF YOU WEREN’T SO BUSY HUNTIN’ DOWN VAGRANTS! WE SAVED YE FROM STARVING AS MUCH AS YE ‘SAVED’ US!”

         “Atanik—” Kilak stopped as Bone glared at him. “Bone,” he corrected, “please forgive us, I never had a choice over my grandfather’s wishes; please do not throw away all we’ve been through, we are kin!”

         Never had a choice… hypocrite. You thought.

         “AH LOST EVERYTHING I CARED ABOOT BECAUSE OF YER PEOPLE’S, YER GRANDFATHER’S, AND YER ANCESTORS’ MISTAKES! WE ALL KNEW WE COULDN’T DESTROY THA’ VAGRANTS, AND YE GOT EVERYONE KILLED ANYWAY! “

         “If I could go back and stop them I would, but I cannot! Please, Atanik, you’re not the only one who lost everything that night!” Kilak pleaded.

         Bone was not convinced, however. “…Aye, maybe ye did lose everything too,” he inhaled deeply, “BUT YER PEOPLE HAD IT COMIN!”

         The mighty bear bellowed wildly, exposing his claws. He charged Bone, and Bone stood up and braced himself for the impact despite his injuries. At the last moment, Kilak stopped himself, butting his head against Bone’s.

         “Take it back, Atanik! That is neither fair nor true!”

         Bone shook his head, “neigh, I won’t, if ah do I’d be lettin’ yer people get away with their crimes; that was their fault.”

         Kilak’s breath quivered like he was about to weep, though his eyes didn't waver.

         “The humans made us this way— Made the vagrants that way, it was never our fault to begin with.”

         You bit your lip. “HEY!” you shouted, “how was that ANYWAY OUR FAULT? That’s completely hypocritical!”

         Kilak snarled, sticking his hand out to grab you, but Bone caught his wrist and squeezed, not at all intimidated by the much larger animal.

         “If ye ever touch ‘im… I promise yer death, Kilak.”

         “It seems you have not forgotten then. It pains me so that you have sided with a human,” Kilak glanced down at you with contempt, “this one belongs in your belly, not by your side, Atanik.”

         Bone butted his head harder and stared up into Kilak's eyes, “I’ll rip yers out if ah ever suspect you might put ‘im there.”

         The two growled once more. As much as you appreciated Bone protecting you, you’d wish he’d learn when to back down from a fight. An injured cat like him can’t win this one, especially against a polar bear.


Then suddenly…
11113121121111121111111121211.title: Atanik & Kilak

111131211211111211111111212112.content:
Rapid stomping approached the tent.
         “What is the meaning of this?” a soft-spoken tenor voice demanded.
         What came through the tent flap was another much taller Polar Bear than Bone’s assailant. His fur was well groomed, with claws colored pearl instead of ivory, and ice white eyes that were nothing like Kilak’s intense blues. The bigger bear glared at the other; face washed in anger.
         “Chief Mishka!” Kilak said.
         “Is there a reason why you are assaulting our guest?” Chief Mishka demanded.
         “Please understand, this is personal, it does not concern you Mishka—”
         “That is Chief Mishka to you— As the leader of our tribe, it very much concerns me, Father!”
         “Father?” you asked out loud. The chief is his son?
         Chief Mishka’s attention was brought to you, his eyes popped open in surprise as he stared in astonishment. Unlike Kilak, his gaze didn’t hold any resentment, instead fascination.
         “Who is this?”
         “He’s mah human” answered Bone.
         “Your human?”
         “Aye.”
         Bone disregarded the fight with his old friend, he was drawn by the younger male and limped towards him. He eyed him out and made what he could of him. He wore a wide smirk.
         “So, yer Kilak’s kid, are ya?”
         “Yes,” answered Mishka, “I believe we have not been introduced; forgive my father’s arrogance, he can be needlessly aggressive on occasion,” he bowed, “welcome to our home.”
         “Tha name’s Bone Snapper,” said Bone as he patted the bear’s shoulder, “neva’ thought I’d get to meet me spirit brother’s kin.”
         Kilak’s bewildered expression spoke for him, what was that all about? Mishka’s face lit up as he gawked at Bone.
         “Atanik? Uncle Atanik? You’re really him?”
         Bone sighed and rubbed his shoulder. “Aye, that ah am— been ah long time since ah been called Atanik.”
         Mishka turned to his father. “Is this true? This Smilodon is the real Atanik, and you failed to mention this?”
         Kilak nodded with his arms crossed. “Yes, Chief Mishka, this truly is my long-lost spirit brother.”
         The mountainous pale beast quite literally bear hugged Bone, crushing him in his grasp as Bone wheezed and thrashed his bushed-up tail.
         “I have heard so much about you, Uncle!”
         It earned a chuckle from you, until it was abruptly cut when you noticed Kilak was watching you with a menacing grimace. The look was accusatory, as if you were invading a happy reunion. You observed the floor submissively. Mishka cautiously rested his Uncle back on the ground, his interest returning to you.
         “Who are you?” he asked.
         Bone coughed, glad to have oxygen again. “Didnae say already? He’s mah human.”
         Mishka frowned. “I’m certain he’s capable of introducing himself.”
         Bone blinked in surprise at the response.
         The bear tread carefully towards you, wary of his every movement. As he came closer, the imposing giant made you shift backwards instinctively. You had only just gotten comfortable with Bone and Thorn, this was a much bigger leap to take.
         “There is no reason to be afraid, human.”
         He placed his monolithic hand behind you and gently scooped you from the table, you gasped as your hand touched his chilly razor-sharp claw. He could skin you without a thought. You pulled your head up to make eye contact, he beamed with delight.
         “Tell me, what is your name?”
         “My name...?”
         “Yes, human, don’t be shy” he said as if speaking to a toddler.
111131211211111211111111212112.title: The Chief Enters

1111312112111112111111112121121.content:
(I changed species names for most of the animals mentioned, any other animal will just be referred to as their normal species name until I come up with something. The names as of now are…
'Marimiut' for Polar Bears; 'Smilotuk' for Sabre-Tooth Tigers; and 'Amaruq' for Dire Wolves. I’ll give names for Elks and Rabbits later on if they become relevant again.
Chiefs will instead be called by their tribes’ word for “leader.” An example would be "Nanuk,” which means “Master of Bears.” So “Chief Mishka” becomes “Nanuk Mishka.”)

         “I-It’s Pup, Nanuk Mishka,” you mutter softly.
         You knew Kilak like to wear more than one face, so what would make Mishka any different? He chuckled, his warm breath bathing you in the stench of fish; you reacted by cupping your mouth with one hand, feeling the moisture land on your skin.
         “There is no need for formalities, human.”
         “Mishka!” called Kilak, swiftly correcting himself upon the other bear’s scowl, “Chief Mishka, you intend to show their kind compassion? This one will exploit a weakness as soon as it senses it!”
         “Enough, Father, I will not allow your prejudice to bring harm to this one, he is an utterly weak and defenseless creature!”
         That last bit stung your dignity a little. Kilak rose where he sat, his muscle-gut shifting underneath his toned pecs.
         “It’s kind are deadlier than you know” he said with arms and shoulders open, “this insect may spell death.”
         Mishka raised an unconvinced brow, then glowered down at you; his broad chest and plump abs glistening in sunlight that pierced through a tent opening.
         “Do you intend harm, little human?”
         “N-N-No, Nanuk Mishka!” you stuttered with your hands out defensively.
         “So you disagree with my father’s barbaric notion of purging you in my stomach?"
         You paled, unsure how to answer. Bone’s claws dug into the bed of furs he rested on as he bit his lower lip. He knew he’d need to play nice to ensure your survival, despite how much he wanted to bash both of these brutes’ heads in. Perhaps he could’ve taken Kilak even with his injury, but he had no chance against Mishka right now. If it were his own life he wouldn’t care, he’d throw it away in a heartbeat out of pride. But you? No. He’d endure anything to keep you from harm.
         Mishka sulked as he caressed your back with a claw, “you poor creature...”
         You shivered.
         “Humans are like us in many ways, you’ve suffered the same as we have. Regardless of your powers, I can at least insure your safety, I promise you that,” he said as he sneered at a displeased Kilak across the tent.
         He knows? He knows about my powers. Bone didn’t tell him, did he?
         You shot an accusatory look. Bone shrugged innocently, as if saying, don’t look at me! Mishka answered the question before you could ask.
         “Worry not, my Uncle has not betrayed your trust. We Marimiut have known the secrets that dwell beneath humans for eons.”
         “Secrets? What secrets?” you asked.
         “Please, human, I am no fool. It’s pointless to feign ignorance. You have already begun your awakening; I sense it in you.”
         “But I don’t know what any of that means— I mean yeah, I… did something, somehow” you said scratching your scalp, “but I don’t know how it happened! I don’t know anything about secrets or awakenings!”
         Mishka scratched his jaw. “Hmmm… I detect no falsehood within you. Indeed, you speak honestly,” he mumbles to himself, “this is strange; I was told humans could not awaken without awareness of their power…”
         “Awaken?” you repeated.
         Kilak rolled his eyes and leaned forward. “For the love of spirits— An awakening means you’ve begun to use your powers only after you understand precisely what they are and how to use them. Awakening without awareness is like swimming the seas with no arms or legs. Impossible.”
         Mishka held a finger up. “Not impossible, but not likely.”
         “Is that bad?” you asked as you twiddled your thumbs.
         Mishka shook his head. “It is simply an anomaly is all, human.”
         “An anomaly… or the insect is deceitful.” said Kilak.
         Mishka growled.
         “You’ve spoken quite enough, Father."
         Kilak backed off.
         Mishka went docile again out of courtesy for you, “It only means you may excel in your abilities sooner than most. Though your kind has likely forgotten about their lost power. Perhaps we can help you better understand yours; do you know what it is?"
         “I’m not sure, it was so surreal— Like dreaming without sleep. I remember I was in the body of an elk when he killed his friend, then I felt his pain when Bone put an axe in him…” you shuddered, “the other time, I saw through the eyes of our friend, Thorn, when I was inside him—”
         You wished you would’ve cut yourself off, because Bone’s face was blood red as he grind his teeth, clearly not happy at the thought of you inside anyone but himself. He glowered at you, expecting an explanation. You shrugged innocently.
         “Fascinating,” said Mishka, “do you remember what caused that to happen?”
         Your attention returned to him, “Bone was about to get shot by the elk, in my head I wanted to save him, but I knew I couldn’t.”
         Bone’s expression softened at that.
         “So, a life or death situation triggers it?” asked Mishka.
         “Maybe, but I don’t really see the use…”
         “When you said you witnessed what the elk saw, are you sure you didn’t once try to move? Why would an elk kill one of their own, have you never stopped to consider that? Perhaps your hand was the one that forced it to be.”
         Then it hit you, and you felt so stupid. When it happened with Thorn, you almost sent him flying into the ground from your excitement. It was no different with the elk, you made him kill his friend. Why did it take you this long to realize? It’s why Bone named you 'Pup' after all; a ‘Puppeteer of Giants.'
         Mishka was intrigued.
         “This ability could make you quite the asset to your tribe, human. Perhaps it may be in both our interest if you stayed for some time."
         You nodded. This Marimiut did provide answers to your questions, but the though couldn't escape you. Why is he so kind to me? Why doesn’t he hate me like his Father? Whatever the reason, at least for now, it was mutually beneficial. Maybe you'd be able to puppeteer a giant once more.
1111312112111112111111112121121.title: Who am I?

11113121121111121111111121211211.content:
Mishka walked with you in palm across the reclaimed wood flooring of the yurt tent and sat a few feet from his father, you and Kilak shifted positions and looked away from each other. Mishka moved closer to his father, perhaps to stir him. Bone inhaled deeply, discreetly rubbing his fist regularly.
         “Uncle Atanik has accompanied you for some time I assume?”
         “Uhh… Well, we’re recent pals, but I trust him.” You said.
         Bone quelled his anxiety by helping himself to the assortment of dried and cooked meat Kilak brought. He chugged a water-skin, glad to have a decent drink after a couple of days.
         “Oh” giggled Mishka as he cupped his maw, “I was under the impression that he was your father.”
         Bone almost spat as he choked on booze, but manage to force it down the wrong hole, causing pain in his lungs. He coughed as he pounded his chest.
         You snickered at the reaction. “No, Nanuk Mishka, he’s not. What made you think that?”
         Mishka shook his head slightly and waved his finger. “As I said, formalities are unnecessary. ‘Mishka’ is fine, human.”
         “Oh… okay, Nanuk Mish—"
         He raised a brow.
         “I mean— Mishka!” you corrected.
         He smiled. “I sense a strong bond between you two, particularly from my Uncle…” he trailed off.
         “I mean, it isn’t a bad assumption. In fact, that’s a good guess.” You said.
         The bear shook his head. “You mistake me. I did not make assumptions, I sensed it within both of you.”
         “Sensed eht? This sum kin'a dumb snow beast joke?” asked Bone with belligerence.
         You saw both hold glares at each other for a split second before Mishka pulled away. You laughed haphazardly, trying to ease tension before it arose.
         “You sensed it? Like some sort of empath or something?” you teased.
         Mishka brightened. “YES! Indeed! How did you know?”
         You awkwardly chuckled until you realized Mishka awaited a response.
         “You’re… You’re serious?”
         Kilak rolled his eyes as he shook his head disapprovingly, knowing Mishka understood the human was joking and guessed on chance.
         Mishka raised his other palm. “I only jest, human. I know you would know nothing about that. However, that was quite an accurate guess.”
         It made sense. You thought these bears had strong intuition, but it’s because they literally see right through you.
         Mishka beamed proudly. “Yes, in that regard we are alike. You have your psychics, and we have our empaths.”
         Bone snorted. “Oi, that nonsense makes for sum good tales for tha little wuns, buh back to yer question, lad. Neigh, ah ain’t his Pops, buh he’s mah human. Still, he’s safer wif’ me than anywun else,” he made sure to point out.
         “Your human?” Mishka reiterated.
         A wrinkle formed between Bone’s snout and brow; he knew he had offended the Nanuk somehow. Mishka rose and slowly approached him, Kilak tensed, but Bone maintained confidence by staying relaxed. You stared at Bone uneasily from the Bear’s lowered hand, shaking your head as if telling him not to say anything stupid.
         Mishka stood above the injured Smilotuk. “Are you implying that you own him?”
         Bone blinked obliviously. “Well, ‘en ah sense, yes.”
         You face palmed, as did Kilak. Admittedly, it felt good that a giant finally acknowledged you as a person.
         “Truly? Should we not inquire Pup on the matter?” he said looking down at you.
         The feeling disappeared. The last thing you wanted to be was a source of conflict sandwiched between two giants.
         “I uhm… Well—”
         “Go on, human. He cannot hurt you in my presence.”
         That statement surprised you. Bone was the giant in the room you were least afraid of. In fact, he might be the only thing keeping you together right now. Bone had to bite his tongue to keep his fury at bay.
         Ah ain’t the monstah ‘ere, he is! Bone thought. Pup’s mine! He thinks ‘e can take ‘im away? He is mah human! No wun takes Bone Snappah’s prey! Bone froze in a cold sweat; he rested his forehead on his palm. His mind wavered. Pup’s human, not prey… Pup’s human, not prey… He echoed like a mantra in his head.
         “Atanik… Are you alright?” asked Kilak.
         “Ye, ahm alright… Just ah stupid thing te say es all.” Bone chuckled.
         “Why is that stupid?” asked Mishka.
         “Cause ahm the wun been protectin’ the little shite since I met ‘im.”
         Bone knew that himself, but now a lingering insecurity dwell in his head. The pressure’s jus gettin’ to me, he thought. He knew he’d never forgive himself if, as Pup’s guardian, he’d be the one to hurt him.
         “Yeah, Bone would never stab me in the back like that!” Pup claimed.
         Bone exhaled with relief; his human’s trust in him did quell a bit of the fear. Thanks, Pup.
         "Bone just feels responsible for me, he doesn’t actually think he owns me. He’s big roar but small bite. Believe me, I even kicked him in the eye and he didn’t care!”
         But ah do own ye, lad, yer mine. Mah human, and ONLY mah human. Bone forced himself to inhale. Neigh, stop.
         The two of you either forgot about the Marimiut’s ability or thought he was exaggerating, because Mishka picked up on Bone’s distress, but sensed none in you.
         “He is not forcing you to say that is he?” he asked, his attention firmly on his Uncle.
         So much for goodwill between family.
         “Of course not!” you shouted, “I’m in an ocean of death every day, and Bone makes me feel safe.”
         Mishka squinted, evaluating your statement.
         “Very well.” he said, then bowed to Bone. “Please forgive my abrasiveness, Uncle. It is the duty of the Nanuk to be thorough when protecting his own and those weaker than himself.”
         “Hah, didnae even take offense, laddie! It’s good Pup ‘as mor than wun looking at for ‘im.”
         No. Pup only needs MEH. Only AH CAN keep ‘im safe. Only WITH ME he’s safe. Only… inside me he can…
         Kilak coughed. “Now that we have that resolved—" he coughed again, "Atanik!”
         Bone perked up, a breech-cloth hit him in the face; he could tell it was his own by the color. It was evident Kilak washed them from the lack of smell Bone prided in having.
         “AYE! Don’t ye go throwin’ things at me fookin’ face!” Bone said, then examined his cloth. “You took mah newest stains outta’ ‘em!” he whined.
         “You are very welcome! But enough of that— I know Smilotuks have no qualms on nudity, but show some modesty here, Atanik!”
         It was then Bone realized he was entirely nude; in utter shamelessness he scratched his balls, bouncing them in front of all of you before sliding into his garments. You and Kilak blushed together, looking away.
         A notion appeared in Kilak’s mind. “Nanuk Mishka, perhaps you could accompany the human… Your uncle and I need to reminisce on the past.”
         His spirit brother scowled at him, not keen on being away from his human. But before he could say anything he was interrupted.
         “You do not mine, do you?” Mishka asked.
         It took you a second to realize his question was directed to you and not your giant. It was strange; the largest out of all giants in the tent, to the point where he almost touched the ceiling, treated you like an equal rather than a pet or servant. Bone obviously had reservations, but the decision wasn’t his.
         You hesitated. “I uh-uhm…”
         Mishka look disheartened but was playing it up. He raised his palms to his face and was giving you puppy dog eyes; needless to say, he wanted to get to know you personally.
         “Not at all.” You relented.
         Mishka grinned from ear to ear. “Wonderful! Father, Uncle— We will see you at evening meal.”
         Kilak and Mishka bowed to each other. You honored their tradition by also bowing. Bone signaled concern, but you gestured as if saying, stop worrying, I’ll be fine. Mishka lifted the rawhide tent flap, you gulped. I hope this is a good idea, you thought.
